column4: expresses surprise; a, taawa ‘oh, there it is’; a, ima aviituq ‘oh, it's not there anymore’"
pronounced with breathy voice to indicate exasperation
an expression of approval or agreement; aanaqsiin? ‘are you going out?’ -- aa ‘yes’

aafkaghtuq ‘it burst’; aafkaghaa ‘he burst it’ / Maalghuk ighuk ugugnaghaam ighukek neghumakek. Taagken aghnam pimakanga, aqsanga kenegraamaan, "Kaay aqsan aafkaghllequq." ‘He ate two legs, hind-quarters of the shrew. Then the woman said to him, while poking at his stomach, “Hey, your stomach will burst.” (UNGIPAGHAGH. 80)

column3: durable material that will not burst
to set things aside; to divide things into groups

column4: aaftuq ‘he separated himself from the others’; aaftaa ‘he separated it from the others, took it from where it was, put it aside’ / aafutut ‘they separated from each other’; = afte-

aagtuq ‘he made a side trip’; aagaa ‘he went over to it while on his way to somewhere else’ / aagvik ‘the place to which one makes a side trip’; Sangwaa taakwagun aagaqegkan, tuqutaqigu. ‘If something happens to come by  this way, kill it.’ (UNGAZ. UNGIP. 62)

aagaaq ‘it swung’ / aagastaa ‘he made it swing’, ‘he pushed her on the swing’; Aagastaqa qevulliighaatekestaamaan aagalghiinaakun. ‘I began to push her on the swing a little more with each back and forth swinging motion.’ (SULUWET 16)

column3: to prolong one's action for a long time; to moan long and mournfully
column4: aagestuq ‘he let out a long moan or kept his action going for a long time’ / qinuyulghii aagestaataghtuq unulqusiq elngaatall ‘the sick one let out long painful cries throughout the night’; mekelghiighhaq aagestaataghtuq qiyatkelluku ‘the little boy prolonged his wailing as he cried’; qepghallghegni aaghestaak yugem taawa ‘oh my, the man is keeping at his work for as long as he can’

column3: to move a little by force; to budge; to change one's mind; for there to be an earthquake
column4: aaghhaghtuq ‘it budged, he changed his mind’; aaghhaghtaa ‘he budged it, he changed her mind’ / nuna aaghhaghtuq ‘the ground moved, there was an earthquake’; nguutnguga alangqughiitama aaghhaghluku ilefkaghaghsimaaqa ‘I made the stone in my ring come loose and fall out’; aaghhaghsaghqaghhaanghilnguq yuuk qenwatlu taawa malikruutesimaat ‘they finally persuaded that very stubborn man to go along with their ideas’

column3: to move freely (as a rope being pulled, or a person's behavior); to slacken
column4: aaghhuq ‘it (rope) is running free; he (person) is not being restrained nor restraining himself’ / aaghhestaa ‘he is letting it run free’; aaghhestaa uyiiq aghveq awatmun igleghsan ‘he let the whale rope flow out as the whale moved away’; aaghhuq yuuk taana qepghaqamini avelghaqiinaghluki ilani piyukellghinaghmitun ‘that man is getting away with doing whatever he wishes with complete disregard for his co-workers’; aaghhestaat taana taghnughhaq elngaatall ‘they certainly are giving that child free rein’

column3: person that can easily be persuaded

column4: Tawaten ataasimi aghneghmi Kiiluuq aaghhneghlliqumalghii esnamun samavek elqwaaghyaghnaluni.’ Then one day Kiiluuq being stubborn went down to the shore to gather seaweed.’ (KIILUUQ 3)

column3: one who is hard to convince; stubborn person; skeptical person
to move by crawling over thin ice
column4: piyaalghii iikusati aaghhutameng aghviimalghii ‘the man who was hunting by foot crossed by drawling  over the thing ice when the cake of ice he was on broke off from the main ice

aaghhuq or aaghhwuq ‘he crawled’; aaghhwaa ‘he crawled over it’ / aaghhwaaghtuq ‘he keeps crawling’; Repall atanga aaghhweregaghmeng aanumalghii, llangaqa pingayuneng ighukelghii. ‘The father went out crawling, looking like he had three legs.’ (UNGIPAGHAGH. 72)

column3: fireball of some sort coming down from mountains (perhaps meteor or comet)
column4: traditionally thought to be connected with a creature dwelling in the rocks behind Gambell; the color is said to be prophetic

column3: to take a route different from usual; to detour; to avoid; to evade; to put rope around or across something
column4: aaghqaghtuq ‘he went a different way’; aaghqaghtaa ‘he didn’t stop at it’ / taagagun aaghqaghsimaaq ‘he went by the far side instead’; aaghqaghtaa tapghaq ‘he put the rope around that part’
aaghqaghtuq ‘he went a different way’; aaghqaghtaa ‘he didn’t stop at it’ / taagagun aaghqaghsimaaq ‘he went by the far side instead’; aaghqaghtaa tapghaq ‘he put the rope around that part’

column3: to detour; to decide for someone without giving him a say
column4: aaghqutaatestegpenasi seghletun pinaqelghiinun ‘don't let them tell you what to do when they are doing wrong’
Chukotkan; called kalleghta by most people on St. Lawrence Island

column3: to comply with the wishes of another
thong holding shank (giimaq) to harpoon shaft
to move a little; to budge; to change one's mind; for there to be an earthquake

column4: aaghwtuq ‘it turned upside down’; aaghwtaa ‘he turned it upside down’; aaghwngaaq ‘it is upside down’; qayuutat ayumiq aaghwtaaghtestesnanighaqiit ‘long ago they discouraged people from leaving wooden platters upside down’ (probably a superstition)
aaghwquq ‘he got bloody’; aaghwqaa ‘he got it bloody’ /

column3: tent with a arched roof; wooden house type with arched roof covered with hide
that one over there; that one going away

column4: aagneghaghtuk ‘they2 (pants) split at the crotch’; aagneghaghtaak ‘he split them2 at the crotch’ /

column3: to have long steps; to have a long stride
crotch of pants; one pace; one step
column4: used in the dual, aagneghek, for one crotch

column3: insulated inner room of the traditional dome-shaped house, the mangteghapik (q.v.)
column4: Aagram ilungi puqlaghllagulghiit, aghnat ilungani raarwiighesnaghluteng ayuqelghiit sungighluteng, tangyeghusighluteng, tukughusighluteng. ‘Because inside the inner room women are quite warm they wear only underwear plus beads, bracelets and anklets.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 1:33); aagra is termed polog ‘bed canopy’ in Russian

column3: guyline at corner of the aagra, the insulated inner room of traditional dome-shaped house
ridgepole supporting the aagra, the insulatedinner room of traditional dome-shaped house
to shoot at even though from a distance
column4: neghsaq nuulghii aatak aagtaghyaghaqa ‘I tried shooting at the seal even though it was far away’

column3: to keep something secret; to let something pass without mentioning it
to bump into something; to make a side trip for (it)
column4: aagutuq ‘he bumped into something’; aagutaa ‘he bumped into it’, ‘he made a side trip for it’ /
aagyugneghutmineng qepghaqanguq ‘he landed himself a job due to his being a persistent person’
ugumiyugsaghluku milughmilghii aagyugtestaa ‘he provoked him so he continued to throw rocks’
aagyugutkaa ‘he picked on him’ / alingtalghii aagyugutkaat alingseghaghaqluku ‘they picked on the person who is easily frightened by trying to scare him’

column3: a game involving coiled lines drawn on the ground which one follows from the outside inward as a particular song is sung
oldsquaw duck (Clangula hyemalis); the cry of the oldsquaw
column4: the true name of the oldsquaw is said to be kangghwaak, while the present word is a sort of nickname based on the cry of the oldsquaw
aawa ‘his blood’, aakwa ‘my blood’; aawuuq ‘it is blood’; see also aaw- ‘to bleed’

column3: small spot or streak of blood
another family in the same clan; the other of a pair of boats cooperating in a hunt; hunting partner; second wife

column4: the name comes from Monday being the second day of the week

column3: broom; besom; wing of bird used as a broom
column4: Chukotkan (R); may be used in the plural for a single broom

column3: ember; soot with grease from an oil lamp

column4: irregular subordinative of aallghite- (rather than aallghinaan or aallghunaan)

column3: block of snow to be used in a heated house
that one over there; the one across the sea; that one on the other side of something; that one over the mountains; that one in the other room
welt put in between the boot sole and the upper on a skin-boot
column4: Aamqutnguut nateghqamllu amiiramllu akulanganilnguut …. ‘There was a welt [put] between the sole and upper [of the boot] ….’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 1:114)

column3: as we know from our experience; as we well understand
column4: aamta ellngitlu aghneghmi amighinaqaqeftut whangkutestun ‘they are putting a skin on their boat today just as we are’; aamta ellngitlu seghleliightut taawa ‘oh, they are grieving greatly (a feeling we understand all too well)’; Mekelghiighuluteng, apangiighhaghputlu aagna, apangiighhaghputlu aamta entaqun seghleghllugumayaghtuq.  ‘Being boys, our little grandfather too, that one, our little grandfather also, as we know maybe he would try to be bad (be mischievous).’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 2:24)"

column3: if that can't be; if that isn't so; if that is so; that being the case
column4: tawani tagilghaaten utaqanaaghamken taawanginaq enkaam aamtaam pipagningiskuvek ungipaannakevnga kitukun ‘come at that time and I'll wait for you, but if you can't, let me know through someone’; tagilghaaten, aamtaam wiin piyunghilkuvek taginghisaghngaaghpek ‘do come over, but if you don't want to, then don't’; taginghisaghngaaghpek aamtaam tagiyukuvek tagilghaaten ‘you don't have to come, but if you want to come, then come’; Aamtaam eltughaanka pillgitngwaaghtut. ‘That being so, my grandchildren treasure the things they have.’ (Sivuq. Nangagh. 3:94); Taawanginaq whanganginanghitunga, anengalguunga. Aamtaam ighlekegkaanganga ugiighnaanghitunga. Aamtaam aangqanganga ugiighllequnga. ‘It’s not only me, I have an older brother. That being the case, if he doesn’t let me I won’t marry you. That being the case, if he does agree I will marry you.’ (UNGIPAGHAGH. 20)"
aamtawha kiigunneghatni quugmeng suyvaghtuq imawha uksungani naangut ‘he would try to gather enough wood during the summer but would run out in the winter’
aanuq ‘he went out’; aanaa ‘he went out of it or went out through it / aanutaa he took it out’

column3: littermate; one born at the same time; a person's contemporary
to drive out; to expel; to force somebody to leave
to press or squeeze out; to put or thrust out
to act as if superior to others; to put on airs; to act conceited
to be big; to be large
to spark as from friction; to make sparks
column4: aanghuutuq ‘it made sparks’ / Uyghagami qamiyegka aanghuutuk igleghsama.’ My sled made sparks as I was going over the rocks.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 5)

column3: to get ready to throw a ball; to "wind up"
to be rather big,  big enough
to concentrate thought and action on what one is doing
column4: aanightuq ‘he is concentrating on what he is doing’ / aanighutaa ‘he is concentrating on it’; cf. anighte-

column3: to leave a building; to rise to the surface
to seep out; to flow out
column4: aanleghaghtuq ‘it seeped out’ / Kagimkaq qantamineng aanleghaghtuq reghilleghqun. ‘Sugar is leaking out of the its container through a hole.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 5)

column3: the number three (in a counting or finger naming jingle for children)
column4: cf. aangqaq; the entire jingle is: aatati, pututati, aanqaghreki, tekiina, kumlu, aasi, taawra, qilughru, milughru, qughru 'one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten'

column3: to rush out; to protrude; to bulge
to hit accidentally as with a stone from a sling

column4: aanqutaa ‘he began (to say, sing) i’t / aanqutiiq ‘he began to sing’; yugem aanqutisaghaanga kaallunga ‘the man began to say something as he reached me’; Ellngan quunpeng aanqutaqii atuutet atulghiini. ‘He always starts the songs for the singers.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 6); cf. aane-
may be used in the plural, aantat, for one midden

column3: to to take out; to bring out; to put out; to give birth to
column4: aantaa ‘he brought it out’ / aantiiq ‘he took something out (particularly a commode for dumping)’; pegnem aantaa ighneni ‘she had a difficult time giving birth to her son’

column3: first one out; first-born child; man who goes outside the first (in the morning); first letter of word, initial

column4: also used in the dual, aanyaghak, for one exit or outlet; qaltak aanyaghametuk ‘the bucket is by the exit; kiiwem aanyaghakek uusqaghtuk ‘the water is deep around the outlet of the river’

aanziightuq ‘he burped’; Aanziighllagyalghiimi sayalghiimi, mighyaghllagyalghiimi taghnughhaam akileghteghllagluku, qiyateghllaget. ‘When it (the creature) belched, doubled over, and threw up violently, the children tumbled out from it crying loudly.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 3:174)

column3: object which is to be sacrificed; prediction
to ask permission; to ask concerning someone or something
column4: aaputuq ‘he asked for permission’; aaputaa ‘he asked her for permission’; Ungazighmiit aaputaqut ellmengllu Arctic Ocean-mun pinaluteng. ‘The Siberians would ask permission (to join), wanting to go to the Arctic Ocean.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 3:118)

yuuk sikugni piyugluni aaqun meghquutkaaguq ‘a man walking on the ice practically fell into the water’; Taana ivenrumeng kaatevzighaghput, aaqun kaasimaaghput iitek. ‘We almost reached that one with the outboarrd motor; almost, we got to it, indeed.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 2:34)"

aarraghtuq ‘he dressed up’; aarraghaa ‘he dressed her up’ ;  Elngaatall siivanlleq tamaana aarraatesluku. ‘They brought the elder(s) there all dressed up.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 2:210); Aarraatkaq igaqraghllagmeng tawaten pinighrakegtepiglluku ulimalluteng. ‘everyone got all dressed up in clothing which they made as fancy as possible.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 3:86)

column3: Singikpak Pt. site east of Southwest Cape on St. Lawrence Is.
former village site west of Cape Chukotskii in Chukotka
the number six (in a counting or finger naming jingle for children)
column4: the entire jingle is: aatati, pututati, aanqaghreki, tekiina, kumlu, aasi, taawra, qilughru, milughru, qughru 'one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten'

column3: narrow thing; something that does not extend far
column4: Aaskestaaghhaanghani kiyang malghugneghet piiqiit, … ‘Whenever it [the sea ice] did not extend far out they always made two [boat paths], …’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 1:134)
aasliightuq ‘he patched a boat’; aasliighaa ‘he patched it’ /

column3: soup of greens and seal blood
former village on east shore of Provideniia Bay; Plover Bay in Chukotka
grease stain in the entrance opening of a winter house
to be wide; to extend far
column4: aastuuq ‘it is wide, extends far; Aastughllagyalghii, kilgaaquteghllagaqelghiit, kiyang whanikumi. ‘It was extended farther, as far as long distance runners were concerned, then than now.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 1:20); Aamta tuvalgunghani tawaten ataasiinaat kenilghet seggaqiit, qayughllak ilangakun tuvaq aastaaqelghii. ‘And, whenever it had shore ice like that they made but one boat path, because the shore ice extended a long way out.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 1:134)

column3: do it anyway; give it a try; let's
column4: used to boost morale; Seghleghunaqukut, yulgutmun kaatngwaaghluta tusaqunneghitem seghletun pinaqukut, aatak qitevunnaqigu! ‘Things are going poorly for us, and now that we have come across a fellow human, because we can’t understand each other we have a problem; give it a try, speak to him in the other language!’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 2:124); Aatak naghuyaqellaankuk meteghlluglliqellaankuk piiqagka. ‘(I’ll) give at a try,  I am trying to talk to the seagull and the raven.’ (UNGIPAGHAGH. 109)"

column3: do it anyway; give it a try; let's
do it anyway; give it a try; let's
the number ‘one’ (in a counting or finger naming jingle for children)
column4: cf. ataasiq; the entire jingle is: aatati, pututati, aanqaghreki, tekiina, kumlu, aasi, taawra, qilughru, milughru, qughru 'one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten'

aatawleginaq mughusimaaq, sakengaghsimangituq ‘he went hunting for nothing, he didn’t get anything’; unangataghalluku tagilghaaten aatawleginaq  neghsaghhnaanghituten, ayveghaghnaanghituten ‘come early in the morning, otherwise you won’t get seals or walrus’"

aatuq ‘it put something on’; aataa ‘he put it on’ / aalluku ‘after putting it on’; aalleqaa ‘he will put it on’; aannaqaa ‘he is going to put it on’; aatkaagaa or aaskaagaa ‘he has put it on’; aasuwaaghaa ‘he feels like wearing it’;

column3: to go out hunting on foot on the ice
column4: sikuk kaanneghegkeni yuget aatghutaqelghiit ‘men go out hunting (on foot) once the ocean ice arrives’

to suddenly and quickly go out (as from room)

column4: aatqaghtuq ‘he or it jerked’; aatqaghtaa ‘he jerked it’/ tumeneng aatqaghtuq ‘he ran off the road’; terelleghmeng piineqegkani aatqaghtaa ‘he painted off the marked line’

column3: to split open suddenly; to get injured severely on the surface of one’s body

aawhkaghtuq or aawhkaghaa ‘spring has come’ / cf. awa(ni)

column3: pair of stars seen at dawn, Altair and Tarared in the constellation of the Eagle

column4: Chukotkan (R); literally, ‘aayiiq, once again’ (aayiiq is a name of a certain spirit, a tughneghaq)
aaykaghtuq ‘he is gambling’; y preceding k questioned

column3: poker or similar card game; gambling

column4: ullghitagma afkuyaa naalkaghtaqa ‘I found the cause of the problem with my wheeled/tracked vehicle’; Naghullgaqluki, pakin'gumakanga nagun iqelqwakun itegaakun, taawa taana tuqusiqaa, pakinellgha qazigyaghaam. Aatgha Anaqsi, Sikneghnii. Afkuyaghhaan. ‘While he was harpooning them, it scratched him somewhere on his little toe, and that’s what killed him, the scratch of a seal. … That was all it took.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 3:22)

column3: thing between two others; middle one

column4: aflengaaq ‘he is thrifty’, ‘he takes care of his things’ /

column4: aflengakaa ‘he is taking care of it’ / Qikmiqa ataasiq tuunluku maalghuk aflengakagka.’ I gave away one of my dogs and kept two.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 8)

column3: thrifty person; one who takes good care of what he has
column4: aflenganghuuq ‘he’s a person who takes good care of what he has’

column4: Estamat aflut piyugutkanka. ‘I walked for four hours.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 132)

column3: to feel sorry for; to sympathize with
for there to be the squeaking sound of a mouse
vole (Microtus sp. ); locally mouse; also slang for lump of dried nasal mucus

this is the interjectional form of the demo. adverb aga(ni) from demo. pronoun aagna(q.v.); Amaaghllak aga estunaquq. ‘There he goes, the wolf is about to slide.’  (AYUM. UNGIP. I:7)"

clothes hanger; clothespin; peg for hanging things; hook for hanging things

column3: peg for hanging things; hook for hanging things

column4: agangsitaghtuq ‘he, or it, it staying away’ / kayut saamkut agangsitaghtat nalleq? ‘why are the fish down there staying away?’

column3: peg for hanging things; hook for hanging things

agepsughtuuq ‘there's a lot of smoke’; agepsughtaaghtuq ‘it has smoke coming out of it’

agghiiq ‘he decided’/ agghiit ‘they are conferring, deciding on something’; agghitkaa ‘he decided concerning it, figured it out’; agghiiq igleghhnaluni ‘he decided to go’

column3: to be spoiled; to be obstinate
column4: cf. agghi; mekelghiighhaq agghiyugniquq ghhuuteghngaatni wata an’gighnaluni ‘the little boy tried to have his way and stay outdoors even though it was cold’

column4: aghelqutuq ‘it moved a little, it budged’; aghelqutaa ‘he moved it a little, he budged it’/

column4: aghhmagtaa ‘he took or used all of it’ /
aghhmeghneqegtaq ‘a sturdy skin or piece of clothing’
literally, ‘its becoming day, every one’; Aghhutanga tamaghhaan takwaaqiit. ‘Every day they would check it.’ (PIYAA. 14)
aghhutkun esla naavuq ‘the weather got bad at dawn’
aghiiq or aghii ‘it got wet’ / cf. aghilluk

column4: aghivaaq ‘she is quarreling with someone, bawling out someone’; aghivaa ‘she is quarreling with her’ / aghivatuk ‘they (two women) are quarreling’
aghliighyugtuq ‘he feels overwhelmed by the tasks facing him’; aghliighyukaa ‘he feels overwhelmed by it’; aghliighnaghtuq ‘it is overwhelming’
aghmigtuq ‘he washed his (own) face’; aghmigaa ‘he washed his (another's) face’ /
used in the dual, aghmigusik, for one washbasin

column3: female bird, fish, or seal or other animal; state of being female

column4: Kiyaghneghem Ataneghpagullghani nekaghqiitut: … allaniighet, aghnaasit, … ‘In God’s Kingdom there is no room for: … adulterers, the effeminate , …’ (1 Corinthians 6.9)
aghnagan uyuq emta ‘hurry up you, knowing how you are’"
aghnaghluni ‘wearing a dress’; direct verbalization of aghnaq ‘woman’

column3: Aghnak River on St. Lawrence Is.
wife-to-be; female to be included in a group; dress material
edible seashore life resembling a mouse in appearance (Boltenia ovifera); “sea onion”
mother's sister's child; parallel cousin on mother's side

column4: Aghnaghaat igaghvigmi aghnangllaatut. ‘The girls made dresses in school.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 11); Yuuk aghnangllaghiiq ighneghminun. ‘The man asked that a certain girl should be the wife for his son.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 11)

sitting by bending one leg resting it on the floor while the other leg is also bent but upright with the foot flat on the floor; aghnapesqighlluteng aghnat avegtughaqut neghuunneghmeggmi ‘sitting woman-style the women are cutting food at meal time’

column3: for the days to get longer

column4: aghneqaghaq ‘earlier today’; Sivuliq aghneq ‘Sunday’; Allgha aghneq ‘Monday’; Pingayaa aghneq ‘Tuesday’; Estamaa aghneq ‘Wednesday’; Tallimaa aghneq ‘Thursday’; Aghvillgha aghneq ‘Friday’; Maaghraghvinlek aghneq ‘Saturday’; Aghnaghaq una qepghaghpenani quunpeng naghaaghllak tamaghhaan aghneq. Aghneq iingunaan qepghanemni, qenwat meghnughaqunga. ‘This girl plays without working every day. When I work all day, I am tired.’ (UNGAZ. UNGIP. 68)

NANGAGH. 2:144); Taakuk ingaghtaqelghiik akeleghraaqluku, llaaghanwha ghhuusigalkanga. ‘ Whenever the two of them lay down to sleep they put him between them, and thus he didn’t get cold.’ (AKIINGQWAGH. 73)

Aklumalleghpigaq Quyanalleghpigaq Kuusma ‘The Poorest Most Thankful Christmas’ (KALLAG. 36); Uteghmun sumeghtaghaatkennemkun Kuusmelleghput nengllugutkullghiini qerngaaghhaamta, aklumaghngaamta, kayutkuteqaghlluta. ‘When I think back (I realize) that we had Christmas being a family gathered together even though we were poor helping each other.’ (KALLAG. 51); cf. aklungi
Ama kiyaghlleghhii aghnaq aklumalghii, ugilek avaqutaghtuqaq, aatgha Arepaki. ‘And there lived a poor woman, with a husband and lots of children, named Arepaki.’ (UNGAZ. UNGIP. 25); cf. aklungi

column3: to put sugar or other things in; to add extra ingredients
column4: akumaa ‘he put sugar (or something else) in it’ / akumutuq ‘he mingled with the others or put in something for himself’; akumutaa ‘he put it into something’
aleghquullghiini wiin akumighaghtaghtuten nepiiqaa ‘please be quiet; you’ve interrupted the conversation’
Sangisiin akumkaghqameng piinsuukemun? ‘Don’t you have anything to add to the beans?’ (SLI JR. DICT. 23)

column3: to grab; catch; to accept a decision or an offer quickly
rumor; news told before it becomes certain
to spread a rumor or news before it becomes certain
column4: Akusqaghtaghtut un’ga kinkut angyiit aghvengniluki. ‘They are quickly spreading the word that someone’s boat out there has caught a whale.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 23)

column3: to be there when something happens; to arrive on time; to be in the right place at the right time
column4: akuuraatuq ‘he was there at the right time’; akuuraataa ‘he brought it on time’ / akuuraatuq Neghestikun maapiluni ‘he arrived just in time for Thanksgiving’

column3: to be at the same place or same time
column4: exact meaning/use questioned; akuuraqwaaquuq ‘he always seems to be hunting in the right place at the right time and catches something’

column3: dough; mixture; baked item of food; Eskimo "ice cream"

column4: akuutuq ‘he is mixing something; akuutaa ‘he is mixing it’ /

column3: time when people are in a hurry; rush; rush hour
column4: akuynaq pivagilgan estugaghmun akilpegaghyaghnaqunga ‘before it gets really busy I’m going to go shop at the store’; akuynami sangwaa puyguyaqunaan ‘don’t forget something during the rush’
Aghnaghaam akuzillgha whangkunneng allanguuq. ‘The girl’s speech is different from ours.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 24)
Piinlighyuwhaalleghmeng Akuzin tawantekaq, … ‘ In the beginning was the Word, …’ (John 1.1)
akuzipigtuq ‘he spoke in the St. Lawrence Is. / Siberian Yupik Eskimo language’

column3: the St. Lawrence Is. / Siberian Yupik Eskimo language
column4: akuzipigestun ‘in the St. Lawrence Is. / Siberian Yupik Eskimo language’

column3: to advise; to urge; to try to persuade
to increase in volume or number or frequency
column4: akwaangightuq ‘it is become more numerous or frequent’ / tepam tepellgha akwaangighyalghiimi esnighqwat tepaghsilghutut ‘when more and more sea life got washed ashore the beachcombers got their fill of sea life’; qawaagem tagillgha akwaangightuq ‘the arrival of birds is becoming more frequent’

column3: to get something and then lose it right away
column4: alaaqitkaa ‘he got it and then lost it’ / unangkaghteng tugungwaaghluku alaaqitkaat ‘they retrieved the seal they killed but then they lost it’

column3: furthermore; also; might as well; it turns out
column4: shows the insistence on something or the continued existence of certain circumstances; siivanlleghita qelghii aatkani kinengllaghaghtesqelluki, alaghrang gaaghaghutqaghtesqumaghmi piiq ‘their elder implored them to dry his clothes and also he begged them to cook for him right away’; tengegkayuget wiintakusikat alaghrang aviitut ‘the airplane that was delayed never did come’; alaghrang piyaafqaama, anuqa iknaqataghapigta wiin ‘I might as well not go because the wind is a little too strong’; ‘Ighennaq alaghrang aghulangigateftuq kayagtaghwaaghyaghaghput pipagningitngwaaghtuq. ‘Ighennaq, it turns out, doesn’t dance. We tried having him dance, but he wouldn’t at all.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 3:132)"

column3: to have a premonition; to expect something to happen
column4: sameng alaghuutaghsigasiin? ‘haven’t you been expecting something to happen?’; sangwaat alaghuutaghsigatut ‘nothing was sensed, expected’

column3: a pie made from reindeer fat and chopped boiled meat
spirit that takes the form of a killer whale
partition between compartments of a ruminant's stomach

column4: alamsaaq ‘he wants to eat more’ / neghepanghitem entaqun alamsaghllaguuq ‘he wants to eat more perhaps on account of not having eaten much’

alangghuyugtuq ‘he misses something, he is feeling a loss’; alangghukaa or alangghuyukaa ‘he feels its loss, feels that he didn't have enough time with it’; asagan mekelghiighhaq tuqulghii elngaatall alangghuyukaa qevuulluku ‘the aunt of the boy who just died is bemoaning the shortness of his life’"

column3: to lose game right after catching it
column4: alaqitkaa ‘he got it and lost it soon after’/ unangkaghteng tugungwaaghluku alaqitkaat ‘after taking hold of the seal they’d caught, they lost it’; alaqitkesaqunaan tugunaqiteggu ‘try to bring it in without losing it’; a in the second syllable is also reported as long
Chukotkan; St. Lawrence Islanders use kamagraq for this;  the elephant is known only through contact with outsiders

column3: to speak to someone; to advise
column4: aleghqughtuq ‘he spoke to someone’; aleghqughaa ‘he spoke to him, giving him advice’ / aleghquutuk ‘they2 conversed’

column3: to stay with a companion; to keep company
to whisper; to joke; to tease; to speak lightly (in any sense)
column4: aleghqumseghaghtuq ‘he whispered’; aleghqumseghaghaa ‘he whispered to her’ /
also used in the dual, aleghquusik, for one such device

column3: but; on the contrary; contrary to what has been said
column4: angyaghnguq tengsimaa, alemeng petugteghwaaqaayaghtuq ‘it (the wind) blew the boat away but then it seemed that it had been securely tied up’; alemeng amiklu sanighyiqaqsaghaqa naqamqun qelpanniit ‘they said it was open but contrary to what had been said I had locked the door’; “Mekelghiighmi ugani, hiik, aanestaaten aghnaghaam.” “Aa, aanestanga.” “Kii, alemeng nengaakegkanka taglaanneghminiki aanesigatii.  Taawa ellnganitaqut.  Allallu aanesigatii.” ‘“You boy (by the door), wow, the woman let you out?” “Yes, she let me out.” “Wow, in contrast to that, she doesn't let my sons-in-law out when she brings them home. They stay with her. They don’t go out anymore.”’ (AYUM. UNGIP. III:12)"

column3: companion; other of a pair; second one; afterbirth
column4: aallgha ‘his companion’ (note the irregular voicelessness of llgh); aallgha igaasim pigu ‘you can have the other pencil’; aallghituq ‘it doesn’t have a mate’; alelguuq ‘he has a companion’

aleveghtuq ‘he wants more food’; aleveghnaqlaataghtuten neqeput palapiguut ‘you’re wanting more again and  our food isn’t so plentiful’; neqmeng nuughtem alevghuteghllaguut ‘on account of the shortage of food everyone wants more’
aleveghtuq ‘he wants more’ / neqmeng nuughtem aleveghtut ‘because of the food shortage they want more’

column3: to walk side by side with (him)
column4: alghapaghaghaa ‘he walked side by side with him’ /

column4: alghightuq ‘he doing it for a second time’; alghighaa ‘he added a second one to it ‘/ alghightuq qayumeng ‘he had a second cup of tea’; Sivungaghhnaqelghii laluramka alghighaa yugem ‘the man is accompanying the white person going to Savoonga’

column3: to covet something; to want more (food or the like)

column4: root; > aliigh-, aliighte-, aliinaghlluk, aliiqaqu-, aliite-
nulighha aliftughtuq maalghugegneng ‘his wife miscarried twice’

column4: aligaaq ‘he longs to go’ / aligavikegkaq ‘a longed-for person’
aligakaa ‘he longs to go to him or it’
aligataqsaghtunga iitek esghaghyaghtughnalusi ‘I am longing to go and see you all’; aligallghii maligunnaluni qenwat aangghaghput ‘she was determined to go so we acquiesced’
aligavikaa ‘he longs to go to him or it’

to keep one's hands inside his parka sleeves
to reveal; to show; to bring into view

column3: to be invisible; to be inaudible

column3: to be visible; to be audible
to be afraid of (him/it); to fear
column4: alikaa ‘he is afraid of him or it’ / cf. alinge-, alikumtaaq

column3: something that is very much feared

column4: often with the implication of "teaching a lesson"; alingseghaghtuq ‘he frightened someone’; alingseghaghaa ‘he frightened him’ / anengaan mekelghiighhaq alingseghaghaa gginaqwaalluugmeng ‘his older brother frightened the child with a scary mask’; nanevgam alingseghaghaa eltughani yakughnameng sikuk pilgulleghqaanayukayek piyaanaqeghllak ‘the old man tried to dissuade his grandson when he wanted to go out hunting by warning him of the possible danger of the sea ice’
qikmiq alingsequluku unaghsimeng qimagtestaa ‘he threatened the dog with a stick so it ran off’

column4: alingtaghtuq ‘he is habitually fearful’ / alingtalghii ‘coward, one who is habitually or excessively fearful or anxious’

alingughyugluni yaywaalingiighhaq aaptineghmeng neghyaghqameng aqumtaaghumalghii aghnelqusiq eslami ‘too timid to ask for something to eat, the poor little orphan sat outside all day long’

column4: alingutkaa ‘he is worried about it or him’ / itegaqa puuvaatalghii qenwat alingutkaqa ‘I'm worried about my foot because it keeps swelling’

often of darkness or of being alone; mekelghiighhaq alingyugumalghii ellnginaghhaaghsami mangteghami unugumaan ‘the little boy became apprehensive when he was left alone in the house as evening's darkness fell’

extension of hallway part of roof of the traditional dome-shaped house, the mangteghapik (q.v.)

column4: perhaps specifically of an area covered by  birds, fish, etc.; iqallugameng uga esnaq aklwaaghluni ayuquq ‘it seems like the beach down there is partially covered by all the tom-cod’; sukilpaq kiwani naayghami nalupiggneghmini repall uyghaget alkwaaghluki ‘sometimes where there are so many auklets on the north side of the mountain they practically cover a large area of rock’

other thing; different thing; more; again
magic; mystery; miracle; unusual and attractive thing
of all different kinds; of various kinds
column4: Iyataamaghpek kiyaghtegpenang; neghaqi. Neqa allaghhiinaq  uglapigtuq. ‘Don’t stay hungry; eat!. Food of all different kinds is plentiful.’ (UNGAZ. UNGIP. 72)

to miss hitting the spot aimed at; to arrive earlier or later than planned

column4: allakaan ‘he by himself’; allakaghmeng ‘they separately the ohters’; Ugusami aghnaghaam angayuqani ugkemeng manisfikluki ugkemeng ellmi allakaghmi taagken iitghumalghii ungavigmun. ‘When it was cooked the girl took food to her parents and then went into the inner sleeping enclosure by herself.’ (UNGIPAGHAGH.  161)

allakaa ‘he considers it different from what it was or from what he expected it to be’ / allakamken elngaatall anglighllagumaaten esghallemneng ima kiik ‘I notice a big difference in you since you have grown so much since I saw you last summer’; elngaatall allakaa gginaan naten lliillgha tuquyugutanganeng aawhkaghhaaneng ‘he noticed the big difference in the appearance of her face due to her long illness’; allakutuk ‘they2 find each other different’; allaki ‘to notice a difference’

ayveghaghluteng enkaam ama allanqik nanughaghlutengllu ‘they had caught a walrus and additionally a polar bear!’; allanqik aghvenglaataamaat awatangaghniistun ‘they caught a whale once again as they did last year’
Chukotkan (R); ellngan ayemsimaa allataq igaasiq ‘he broke someone else’s pencil in half’

column4: allgeghtuq ‘it appeared, he was born’ / allgeghtaa ‘he brought it into existence, he obtained it’; kiighwyat allgeghtut ‘the northern lights appeared’; naken allgeghtaqsigu? ‘where did you get it?’; allgeghtaq ‘something acquired’; allgeghutaa ‘he obtained or created something for it’; Pingayut yuget allgeghtut naaygham awatanganeng. ‘Three men appeared from behind the mountain.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 24); Aghnam taghnughhaghaa allgeqaaguq upenghami. ‘The woman’s baby was born in the spring.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 24)

sock knitted of yarn; foot wrapping used in place of a sock

column4: naatghiimaak kaamgegka, allngikaghqek ‘my boots have worn out soles, please patch them’
Chukotkan (R); allngiguluni iqalluk igleghsimaaq ‘the fish went in a school’

column3: diving bird or other thing; submarine

column4: allughqiiq ‘he adopted (a child)’; allughqii ‘he adopted him ‘/ allughqilleqaa ‘he will adopt him’

column4: cf. allungak; see item 1 on list in Oozeva et al. 2004

column3: to act, or act on (it), entirely or almost entirely
column4: allulluteng ‘essentially all of them’; allulluku iitek aqavzik inghumakangat ‘they picked all or almost all the salmonberries in one area’; … net allulluteng igleghlleghhiit qimugsimeng. ‘… the household or family moving together by dogteam.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 136); cf. allumyagte-

column3: to be as expected; to stay the same
column4: almesiquq or almesiqaa ‘that's the way it is’; Almesiqeftaa nutem tawaten mesagllak. ‘It was always boggy there.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 2:4)

column3: Algneeyak Pt. on St. Lawrence Is.
to jumble things; to mess things up
column4: alngunaghqusimiit nekeghqughwaaqat igat ‘they jumbled up the books that were neatly put away’; ivaghiluni saghya alngunaghqusimaa ‘he messed up everything when he was looking for something’; alngunaghqutii ulimasit ‘he messed up the tools’

Kina alngunak yuuk ateghaataquq aqfaquq piinlinghani. Nukalpigaq iingunaghmi avelghaghyaghqaanghilnguq tawavek. ‘Any man goes down when the running starts. All young men must not refrain from taking part in that.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 1:48); Iteghluni elngaatall pangalgaghtaamalghii alngunak tamaani teghigniqepiglluni. ’After he came in he ran all around at random enjoying himself very much.’ (IGHSANI. AFSENG. 3); Iwernga whanga piimsi, kitum alngunak ugumiyaguskumigu yulgutni, nanqigtivigmun aglaghsaqleguuq. ‘However I say to you that whosoever hates his fellow, is liable to judgment.’ (Matthew 5:22)"

column3: to pass through (an obstacle, physical or otherwise); to go through

alqimaghtuq ‘he licked something’; alqimaghaa ‘he licked it’ /

column4: so called because it seems as if a hollow has been licked out there
angwaaghutem taam alaa quupaghsimaaq ‘the blade of that paddle is cracked’; ilanga aluq kenlemikun ayemumaaq ‘the blade broke off at the crack’

column3: broad knife, similar to a scraper, on a long shaft, used for butchering whale in the water

column4: Aqfaqumi tamaakut sukaaghikat, paghyuneghlluget kayaalqiikayuget.  Ama tughumghatmi, iknaqelghiit tughumghallget yugiqengegkayuget. ‘In running, those who have become fast and don’t wear down easily win. Also, in wrestling, those who are strong and who are skilled wrestlers win.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 1:50); cf. saama"

the wolf is found in Chukotka but not on St. Lawrence Is.; Amaaghllak pilaataghtuq, “Iluuq.” “Aay!” “Waamtamken, nayagitunga, avangitunga!” The big wolf said then, “Hey, pal.” “Yes?”  “ I fooled you. I don’t have a sister, I don’t have one!’ (KALLAG. 21); Takulleqiisi penniighsugnighqelluteng, taawanginaq ugighsalghiistun amaastun ayuqut. ‘They come to you trying to appear like sheep, but actually they are like fierce wolves.’ (Matthew 7.15)

column3: baby bird; auklet chick; person who is too young for a given situation (slang)
to be in line with each other in someone's sight

amaghtuq ‘he carried someone’ amaghaa ‘he carried him’ /

column3: to continue to carry on one’s shoulders
overlapping slab(s) of ice along a crack in a field of sea ice
column4: see item 3 on list in Oozeva et al. 2004

column3: site in Chukotka on Ittygran Island
line down the middle of something; line down the back of a whale from the mid-area to the fluke

column3: opposite, or back, side of something

Enkaam amalka ayumiqulleq kaspugtaquq. ‘Most of the people have a memorial (of the dead) ceremony somewhere. Some perform it at their boat. Most everybody does it. Then, it's like, it concludes the year.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 1:242)"
Amalleqa amiirii aghvigluki yataaghqellghi piiqiit keligaghwaaghluki. ‘Also after they washed their (the birds’) skins, they prepared them, scraping them.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 1:106)"
amaqaa ‘he carried it on his back’ / < amagh-?-
Amarakaghmii ‘an American’; also used in Chukotka

column3: to carry someone on one’s back
a game played by boys who throw a stick on a line

column4: amawha amik uumgaqa anuqem qelpeghtaa ‘whenever I close the door the wind opens it’

column3: to become or make narrow or thin; to slim down
column4: amellayiiq ‘he slimmed down’; amellayii ‘he made it narrow’ or ‘he slimmed down’ / kemgighyalghiimi weni amellayimaa ‘she lost some weight and became slimmer’; uunghaq amellayiluku llaaghanwha piniightaa ‘making the harpoon narrower it’s better now’
ameltuuq ‘it is wide’ / kiiwek ameltuuk ‘the river is wide’; ameltuqaq ‘wide thing’

column3: then; there; but come to think of it, yes (indeed)
column4: Amen quyakaaguq umiilek elngaatall. Piniipigleghhiit qepghaghtet taakut iflakaayalghiit unguvaslaataghniluki. ‘Yes, the chief was very much happy. For keeping the really good workers who were lost, alive.’ (PANGEGH. 58)"

Kaviingnaquteperewaaghllak, katam maaten tugutluggnaqeghllallemtestun. Amenam maligunnaqaqsalghiinga kaviighniighmun, taawa uqengeghmetaqelghiinga. ‘It was all about trying to get foxes, like how we now try to get ivory. So then when I tagged along in trapping foxes, I would feel very satisfied.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 2:174)"

Nenglutuqaq, iiggesnanighaqegkanginkut neghsameng nuyaaghqiinayukamta amenqun tepa sangwaa aliighnayukan ighlekeluugutangat. ‘There were old underground dwellings they would tell us not to dig in case we ward off the seals; as you know, their reason not to do so is that some odor might come out.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 3:66)"

Elngaatall akilpegaaq … kaviiq, inwa kalngagaq amsakleghii, amenqun aangeghllalghiit maakut. ‘There was a lot of trading going on … for fox; a small sack [to hold them] wasn’t used but rather those large ones.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 3:144); Aangelghiitlu, amsakelghiitlu aghveghet iqallugsagnitut. ‘Big ones and small ones, whales are somewhat like fish.’ (AANGHHAQ 64); cf. amsakeneq, amsakaghtaq
used (only?) with possessed endings; Kayagtaqegkanginkut amsakellghinaaneng, nuugtunghani. ‘He urged us [only to shoot] the very smallest ones as being easiest to pull.’ cf. amsakeneq, amsakelghii

used (only?) with possessed endings; Taagken yugem pimakanga, “Una amsakenghat qaaknaqaqa Honda-gpenun qayughllak Honda-gken mekestaghhaak.” ‘Then the man said to me, “I’m going to put the smallest one of them on your Honda because your Honda is small.’ (AKIINGQWAGH. 38); cf. amsakelleq

column3: to escape from; to struggle through; to wait out
column4: eslalluk aningughhneghsiimakangat yuget igleghsughngaaghmeng ‘the men waited out the rain before they moved on’; ighninghhaghhaq kaviqragllagluni aningughlluumaaq ‘the infant escaped the chicken pox epidemic’
mellaasaghiinkut sikum taglamun iwernga aningughvigek kaatagput uwani ‘we almost got caught in the ice while coming home but we found a way out in the area further west’
aningwaaghtuq or aningwaaghaa ‘he got a boil’ /

column3: to speak or sing loudly (of men); to raise one’s voice to emphasize what one is saying
column4: anpaghquq ‘he raised his voice’; atulghiit saghiighqesalghiimeng anpaghqut ‘when the singers really got enthusiastic they sang loud’; sangami taana anpaghqa? ‘why is that person so loud?’

anughaquq ‘he exercised’ / aqelqaghniighyaghqasi anughaquteki ‘train to challenge your visitors (who are coming to compete)’; kayaalqiinaluteng anughaqegkaagut ‘they were training and exercising so that they could win’

anumikaa or anumiyukaa ‘he favors him or feels concern for him’; anuminaghtuq ‘he is such that people watch out for him or favor him’; anuminaayugtuq ‘he acts in such a way that people will favor him’; uninnaqsaghaa anumiyukaa ‘he was going to leave her behind but felt concerned about her’

column3: wind that is picking up; breeze
column4: Esgha, enngaatall pinightuten, kinquvek anuqataghaghmi whanga piineqnakevnga. ‘Look you are very fine, when you dry in the breeze  you can paint me.’ (AANGHHAQ 27)

column3: permanent or eternal ice or snow
to be tired of something that is annoying or painful
column4: anusigaataa ‘he is tired of it’; Mekelghiighhaam gguusiqelleni anusigaalluku gguutniightemun piiq. ‘The little boy got tired of his toothache and went to the dentist.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 26)

column3: to not want to repeat one's actions due to having seen their consequences; to have "learned one's lesson"
column4: anusimightuq ‘he won't repeat what he did’; ‘anusimightaa he made it so that he won't repeat what he did, "taught him a lesson"’/ Aghnaghaghhaq qalingunani an’gighluni anusimightuq qayughllak aghighllagaa. ‘The little girl learned her lesson from staying out without a raincoat because she got all wet.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 26)
Taagken nanqigtistem kelengakistemun anusimingllaghtesnayukangaten. ‘And the judge would punish you to the maximum extent.’ (Matthew 5:25)

column3: to estimate size; to give directions; to set the price of something

column4: Chukotkan (R); questioned; cf. anaavak ‘net for catching birds’

column3: to beckon; to gesture to come

column3: to cry and fuss without reason (of children)

apallaa ‘his reason’; Tengegkayuget taginghitut apalluqluku eslalluk. ‘The airplane did not come on account of the rain.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 30)

gift of food in honor of new baby given by baby’s parents going house to house
Upapak Pt. on St. Lawrence Is.

column3: Apavawook Cape on St. Lawrence Is.

DICT. 31)

apeghiightuq ‘it got finished’; apeghiighaa ‘he finished it’ / apeghiiqaq ‘finished work’; Neneghmeng apeghiighyamek allighat saaglluki ingaghllutek qavaamalghiik.’ ‘Whey they2 finished eating, after spreading the sleeping mat they lay down and slept.’ (UNGAZ. UNGIP.  13); Taagken apeghiighluteng neghuutut siivanlleghet, … ‘After they did that, the elders ate together, …’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 2:190)

apeghiighsaghtuq ‘he got ready’; apeghiighsaghaa ‘he got it ready’ / nanevgaq ellnginaghhaq kitumtuq apeghiighsaataqagu neghyaghqameng ‘I wonder who gets food ready for the old man who lives all alone’

column3: honorable one; famous one; well-known one

column4: apeghtughaa ‘he taught him’ / apeghtughiiq ‘he taught, is teaching’

column3: to get something ready; to finish something

column3: to make one feel obligated; to be the recipient of hints that someone needs or wants something
column4: Nateghmi utaqiilghaaten. Legan kanaaghlluku aqupileghnaghqeghngaata wata, qineghsaqunang. ‘Stay in the outer room. Just hand it in to them; no matter how much they coax or hint, don’t even look in.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 3:198)

column3: to ask hesitantly; to hint to be given something

column4: Atamnun tuunagka aqupileghsaghaatkegkek ulimaaghminun atuqnalukek, usputaasiqumaagkenka iyaqraasiqumaagkenka. ‘I gave it to my father since he kept hinting that he could use it for carving, measuring things, and decorating (his carvings).’ (KALLAG. 49)

column3: to come to someone’s aid; to help
column4: ullghitakek yugem anigumi apumgullutek nusuneghmeng aghughlukek, eltughani kayagtaqaa estugaghmun, “mekelghiighet naliitanguq aqupilqennaqlitnga” ‘a man got his vehicle stuck in the snow and couldn’t pull it out so he sent his grandson to the store to ask, “are there any boys who can come help me”

column3: game for young boys, played with two sticks
column4: one stick, on the ground, has a small peg near the end while the other is held in the hand and has a string tied to the end; the other end of the string is wrapped around the peg on the stick on the ground; jerking the hand-held stick makes the other stick jump into the air and then slowly gyrate to the ground; formerly this game was played in celebration of catching a whale

column3: to shout; to yell; to scream; to holler
column4: araghtuq ‘he shouted’; araghaa ‘he shouted at her’ / aratuqaq ‘one who screams a lot’

old walrus skin on a winter tent

unugsighngaaghmeng asanut pinitun piqaghtaqegkuyeng ‘as long as they behave it is alright for them stay out late’; asanut pinighluki nagaqumteki itagnaghillequkut ‘at least if we hear that they are okay we’ll be fine’; Asanut elpek espamavek tunuqlighhamnnun aglaghpenang piiqi! ‘At least, you must never to to that one back there.’ (UNGIPAGHAGH. 134)"

asingani ‘under it, lower part of it’; asingighaa ‘he put something under it’; naaygham asilighneghani ‘on the lower part of the mountain’; asingaaneng ‘from the bottom of it’; asiinganeng ‘from the very bottom’

back part of a quadruped animal

Enkaam qafsina asighneq, qulaneng uglaghaqluku asightaqluku sangwaa. ‘And how many [in] a bundle? -- they would bundle them, more than ten together.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 1:92)
asighqaa ‘he tied it, or him, up’

pad put under a thing to raise it, to protect the surface underneath, catch a leak, etc.; base

stitches on the bow of a skin boat on the inner and outer surfaces

column4: asivaghtuq ‘it went down’; asivaghaa ‘he lowered it’ /

column3: come on; you'd better; and also

column4: Neghighluku yuget nulighqullghiit taghnughhangenghinneghmeggni yuuk nuliilek aapneghmegteggu nuliitek naavghutaqluku pinalutek taghnughhangnalutek taghnughhiilnguuk. Yugenkuk nulighqullghhik aapsimakegket saaqwlighhaagteng nek asunnalutek yugek. ‘Long ago men with their wives who can’t bear children would ask another man to trade wives so that the childless couple could have a child. A man and his wife asked their neighbor if he could exhanges wives.’ (SULUWET 108)

column3: to be the only one remaining
column4: ataasighhaaghtuq ‘it was the only one left’

column3: to become, or cause to become, one; to make up one’s mind
column4: Umyugagka ataasiightagka suflugaq tukfighnaluku. ‘I made up my mind to buy the gun.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 169)

ataasiq qilugtuq ‘one barked’; ataasimeng qikmilguunga ‘I have one dog’; the plural ataasit, is used to indicate that a noun, though grammatically plural, actually indicates a single entity (or a single kind of entity); for example, ataasit angyat ‘one boat’; ataasit tengegkayuget nalugtut ‘an airplane landed’; Whakenwhaa ghhataquvek mengteghat ataasit kaalleqaten. ‘When you leave from here you will arrive at a single house.’ (UNIGPAGHAGH. 69); Ataasit neqet taakut eghqwaaghusaqaqut. ‘For their offerings they used one and the same kind of food.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 1:210); Igleghuteghllagluki angyat ataasit…. ‘They moved one boat a long way (on the ice)….’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 3:116); the dual, ataasik, is used to indicate that a noun, though grammatically dual, actually does indicate a single entity and not two entities; for example, ataasik salngagek ‘one box’; Taagken tawaten uyegsimalutung naanguk qenwat ataasik. ‘The one [case of goods] which we were distributing from ran out.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 3:126); Naaka pingayugneghneng qiipaghalek. Ataasik qepghaasikek gaaghusikek. ‘My mother had three cloth cover parkas. One was for working and cooking.’ (SULUWET 13; and note that for ‘(one) cloth cover parka’, the dual, qiipaghaak, is often used )

column3: paternal uncle's child; parallel cousin on father's side

column3: to put (it) down (into something); to put into liquid

'[They would go] jigging, when sculpins were present, drying it, and putting it in oil. Cod too, like that they'd sometimes put in oil [to preserve it].' (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 1:244)

column4: atengllaghtuq ‘he came up with a name’
aatgha ‘his name’; atepiga ‘his real name, his Yupik name’; aatqa ‘my name’; aatghen ‘your name’

column3: Atuk Mtn. (and the salty lake near the summit) on St. Lawrence Is.
it happened although we no longer wanted it to; it happened too late; unfortunately however
column4: iitek ighneni qelghwaaghyaghaa angyiisqelluku unaaq, qavaaniluni ighsaaq, atgenra kesiimiita maketuq angyaghnaluni ‘he tried to have his son go boating this morning, he didn’t want to go because he was asleep, too late, after they left, he got up to go boating’; atgenra tengegkayuget kaatut uteghsimaghma ‘the airplane got here anyway after I decided not to go back’; Elngaatalnguq quunpeng esnighqwaghaqelghii taana Singaaweteghllak. Sameng naalkunnaluni elqwaaghhaghmeng. Atgenra avangisagllak. ‘It is said Singaaweteghllak was so very often combing the beach to try to find some seaweeds. But unfortunately there wasn’t any.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 2:236)"

column3: to go down toward the beach; to go from Chukotka to St. Lawrence Is.
to dive into deep water and stay there for a long time without coming up for air
to take one’s hunting equipment down to the beach preparatory to going out hunting by boat
a certain slope east of Gambell which dogteams used to use as a route down into the village

column4: atghiiguq ‘he went down (the hill) gradually’; atghiigaa ‘he went down on it gradually’ / Uusneghwaaq tevluku atghiiyami sukangitesighwaaghumalghii. ‘After going over the small hill, when he went gradually down, he made the pretense of going slowly.’ (UNGIPAGHAGH. 69)

column3: a contest of strength in which contestants pull each other's hooked middle fingers
loop for middle finger at end of a sling

column4: atighaa panini naamineng ‘he named his daughter after his mother’

atightughtuq ‘he read’; atightughaa ‘he read it’ / atightughyaghqat ‘things to be read such as brochures, magazines, pamphlets, etc.’; atightughyuggaaghusit ‘the first reader’ (name of a Yupik primer)
usually plural, atightullghet, for reading material; aghnaghaam atightullgha pinightuq ‘her way of reading is nice’
atiiqaa naani ‘he named someone after his mother’

column3: to single out; to shade in; to emphasize

column4: atkugtuq ‘he put on a parka’; atkugaa ‘he put a parka on her’ /
also dual for one, especially for a bird skin and feathers parka: atkugegka ‘my parka’
Chukotkan (R); used in the dual, akuraaghllagek, for one coat

column3: garment made from sealskin with European material sewed on it
column4: Chukotkan (R); used in the dual, atkuraaghek,  for one such garment
used in the dual, atkuyaagek, for one such garment

woman's tattoo on the sides of her nose; front seam with piping on skin-boot
column4: Iik, iluuq, nayaka tugunayaghan estamaneng atngaghutelek ‘Look, pal, you can take my sister who has four tatoo lines on her nose’ (AYUM. UNGIP. I:8); = atngaghutaq

column3: to tattoo on the side of the nose
woman's tattoo on the sides of her nose; front seam with piping on skin-boot
former village between Cape Stoletia and Cape Lesovskogo in Chukotka
to make equal in some sense
column4: Chukotkan (R); kingutkat atunekiitaqut sivulighnun ‘the ones who came in late are getting themselves equal to the first ones’; cf. atunem

yupiklu laluramkallu neghuutuk atunem ‘the Yupik Eskimo and the white man ate together’; Unaami nunamnnun aglaghhaakut. Wiin iteghaalluta nayagput tagimaluku, enkaam atunem neghelghaakut. ‘Let’s go to our village tomorrow. But for now, let’s go inside while our sister is coming, then let’s eat together.’ (UNGAZ. UNGIP. 22); Tawaten igleghteghngaaghmeng tekeghaq qemighyuk inga aliighaat, iiwen qemighyugmeng taagken mayughaqut, amaken yugemllu atunem. Atunem aliighutut. ‘As they were going, they were approaching a hill on a point; just as they were climbing the hill, a man at the same time was coming from the other side. They appeared to each other at the same time.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 2:124)"

column3: hide of sea mammal (especially bearded seal); bearded seal or other sea mammal skin before it is dried
column4: of bearded seal or female walrus, use for boat covering, as a mat, as boot-sole material, etc.; cf. atungaq; Atungagmeng aangelghiimeng, amsakaghtameng, iwhanimeng nateghqaqegkayuguyaghpetut. ‘Large, or small, bearded seal hides were used for making the soles of mukluks.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 1:98)

column3: skin of a young bearded seal
useful thing; thing being used; singing
column4: atii aatkat nutaghaagut ‘the clothes she is wearing are new’; ighneghma atii ulimghusit angagan tuunkaqii ‘the tools my son is using were given to him by his uncle’; Enkaangaam naqam enra-aq atuq taana, yupigem ataa igleghutaqeftaat salin. ‘And then there was singing, Eskimo singing, and they continued to do that.’ (PANGEGH. 21)
atuqaa ‘he wore it or used it ‘/
apparently this is the only Yupik word that ends in p

column3: oh yes, now I remember what it was I wanted to say
column4: atwhay aqfaaghhnaken puygukan ‘oh yes, would you please get that thing which you had forgotten’; Angyat entaqun atwhay kaatkaagutlu. Aghnalguutqun tawani tumighqaataqngamta maaken. ‘A boat probably arrived too, I remember. They had women there when we went across to Siberia.’ (PANGEGH. 32); Seghleghhalek elngaatall upughaat. Atalgukaghaa taana atwhaynguq nulighhituq. ‘How great, they were very hospitable to him. Oh yeah! It is said his cousin had no wife.’ (AYUM. UNGIP. III:33)"

column3: to be relieved of pain; to slacken (rain, snow, traffic); to diminish
column4: Ineghteghngaatni mekelghiighhaam umyugaghhaagkeneng avaaghigalnguq aligatellgha naayghamun. ‘Even though they warned him against it, the little boy’s desire to go up the mountain never slackened.’ (AKIINGQWAGH. 49)

column3: for there to be nothing left
to be or have none; to be nothing at all
former village in Chukotka; East Head
column4: see Map 2 in Appendices; see also Avatmiit

column3: to lack something; to have none
column4: avangilnguq ‘one who doesn’t have something, or is lacking things in general’

column3: without something; without having something; with nothing
for there to be nothing left
part of a skin boat (upper part of rib?)
a woman who gives birth only to children that die

column4: avaqutanka ‘my children’; avaqutalguuq ‘he has children’; avaqutiituq ‘he has no children’

column3: to have a child; to give birth

column4: avaraaq ‘she kept her mind off something unpleasant’; iilqelghiit avaranaqumanginaghluteng pinightut ‘it is good to try to cheer up those who are depressed’; avaranaluki naghaaghtestaqluki pineghlliqelleghqiitneng ‘in order to distract them from going astray, let them play’; avarasqelluku laalighfikaa ‘she visited her to cheer her up’
avegtuq ‘it divided in two’; aavgaa ‘he divided it, split it’ / aavgutuq neqmeng ‘he cut off or separated some food for himself’; aavgutaa aghnaq ‘he divided in two, giving half to the woman’

column3: to dice meat; to cut up meat into bite size pieces; to slice meat
column4: avegtughtuq ‘he sliced up some meat’; avegtughaa ‘he sliced it up’ /

Aghnam pimakanga, "Ataasighhaq naasiiqaghhu." Taagken mekelghiighem ataasiq avegtughaq neghumakanga. ‘The woman said to him, “Try one little bit.” And then the boy ate one tidbit of food.’ (UNGAZ. UNGIP. 53)
Chukotkan (R); ellnga avelemkiiquq angyaghpagmun ‘he is rushing to the ship’

column3: to not go to an event; to miss an event; to leave out; to not include; to avoid
column4: avelghaghtuq ‘he missed something, didn't go’; avelghaghaa ‘he left him alone, didn’t include him/it’ / avelghiigatut ‘they never missed the opportunity [to do something]’; Aghhunneghagu avelghaghpenateng navek piiqluteng. ‘Every day without missing an opportunity they would go out somewhere.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 1:244)

column3: to be energetic; to be full of pep
to rush; to be in a hurry; to act energetically
to distract or be distracted from one's problems or bad tendencies
column4: avernguuq ‘he is distracting himself from his trouble or grief as by thinking about something else or keeping busy’; averngwaa (or averngustaa) ‘he is distracting him’ / seghletun pinaqelghiineng avaralghiit sameng pinilghiimeng pistaqluki llaaghanwha averngustaqiit nelliqelleghqiitneng ‘it is good to distract those who might do wrong by leading them toward something enjoyable’
Chukotkan (R); angyallightem aveyugsaghaqaa sivuyagta guutesqelluku ‘the captain is telling the front man to hurry up and shoot’

column3: to have something keep coming to mind; to not be able to get thoughts out of one's mind; to be obsessed
column4: avighaatuq ‘he keeps thinking about something’; avighaataa ‘he keeps thinking about it, can't get it out of his mind’ / ilagaan aghnelqusiq avilghaatkumakanga ‘he thought about the song all day’

column3: to have a ringing in one's ears; to ring (of the ears)
column4: aviiguq ‘he has a ringing in his ears, his ears are ringing; it (ear) is ringing’

column4: yuggaq mangteghamun uuglluni aviiquuq ‘the man climbed to the roof of the house and shouted to announce something’
aviightuq ‘he wiped something’; aviighaa ‘he wiped it’ / aviighusiq or aviighusqaq ‘wiping rag’

column3: to not be there anymore; to die; to disappear
column4: Qilagwaaghllak aganlenguq aviighutuq. ‘The dark cloud over there disappeared’ (SLI JR. DICT. 38); Aghnaq aviighusimaaq. ‘The lady has passed away.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 38)

column3: cry of whale or bearded seal

column4: aviillgha ‘its absence’; used in possessed localis, but with absolutive subject of underlying verb rather than with relative possessor: Yuuk aviilghani, iitghumalghii. ‘When the man was away, it hid.’ (UNGAZ. UNGIP. 66)

column3: song that women perfom when a whale has been caught
to be absent; to be gone; to not be here

column4: Akilpegaghniighluta apeghiighyamta, tent-a (tiinta), qawaagniikghusiq, suflugaq, egllu, avlawa, iingunaqaghtaan tukfightughaa sameng nuughyaghqaagpenanga, … ‘We traded and in the end he had bought a tent, shotgun, rifle, stove, and flour, so I would not lack anything, …’  (SIVUQAM. NANGAGH. 2:60); = evlawa

column4: avleqaghtaa ‘she used a bola to catch it’ / avleqaghsimakanga ‘he did use a bola on it’

column4: avughtuq ‘he sorted things, set some aside’; avughii ‘he sorted them, set them (or some of them) asid’e / avughyaghqat ‘things to be sorted’; avuutaa ‘he sorted things for her’
avuteghquq ‘he regrets something’ / avuteghqutkaa ‘he regrets it’

column4: avyaawiiq ‘he is being careless’ / avyaawiiqelghiit enkaam pituumangigalnguut ‘they misuse things and so they end up with nothing’

obscured demonstrative base; only the demonstrative adverb forms exist and not any corresponding demonstrative pronoun forms; > awaliq, awani, awata, awatghute-, awatiigh-, awatmun, awavagh-, aawhkaghhaani, aawhkaghtaq, aawhkan, aawhkayaghaq;

column3: right on the other side of it; on the very next day

column4: awalightuq ‘he brought over food ‘/ cf. awa(ni)

column3: drifting ice outside of the pack ice
the one right on the other side of something

column4: awalighneghani ‘on the other side of it’

column3: food or  other item brought over as a gift
column4: Asagma awaliisaa neghsam neqanga gaaghaqa. ‘I cooked the seal meat my aunt brought over.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 39)

column3: the one on the other side

column4: “Awalmiggaghmeng saghnaaqitek," piiqiinkut. Awalmiggaghmeng saghnaaqelghiikut. Taakwani sangwaat masugkwaaghhaat. Kaannemta estegmineng nusugluku uyghaggaq qateghrakegtaq, aghneghllak una awalmik peqaghhaat lliluki awalmiggaat taakut. ‘“Gather little husks,” he told us. We gathered little the little husks. Also, some sort of fibrous old roots. When we arrived he pulled from his pocket a little whitish stone, and all day he’d array the husks and tundra moss with the husks.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 2:146)
demonstrative adverb, localis case; anaphoric localis adverb: taawani ‘there, over there at a distance’

column3: area on the other side; last year
column4: mangtegham awatangani (awatngani) ‘in the area on the other side of the house’; awatanganeng or awatnganeng ‘from the other side of it’; Awatangani mangteghaghput taaqegkaaguq. ‘Our house was finished last year.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 39)

column3: to make a sealskin float or poke
column4: Neghsapigmeng unanglunga awataghpiiqa. ‘I caught a seal and made it into a poke.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 118)

column3: to overshoot; to jump or otherwise pass over (it); to miss the mark by going over (it)
column4: awatghutuq ‘it missed the mark going over it’ awatghutaa ‘it went over it’ / neghsaq guutkani awatghutaa ‘he shot at the seal but the bullet went over it’; Milughyaqminigu -- milunghatni legan nalugutaqelghii ulaagha awatghulluku. ‘When she threw it at it, whenever she threw her woman’s-knife at it, she missed hitting it when the knife landed.’ (QATEP. 20)

column3: to lose something by its escaping
column4: awatiightuq ‘he lost something’; awatiighaa ‘he lost it’ / awatiiqaq ‘one that escaped’; unkusenka awatiighumalghiit ‘my trap lost something when it escaped from the trap’

column3: twin looped anchor thong attached to flippers of a sealskin harpoon-line float
thing of last year; thing from the other side
to go farther away (especially of something drifting away)
to move farther away; to drift out; to carry or take farther away; to calm down (of weather)
column4: unaghsighhaq miluutkaqa qagim awavaataa ‘the wave caused the stick I threw to drift further out’; siku awavaghtuq ‘the ice drifted out’; umegneq awavaghaqaa ‘the snow storm is dying down’

awaziqluku yimikumanghitaqa ‘since she is a relative I wasn’t shy with her’; awaziqluku ayuqan yiminiituq tukuqelleghqaa ‘since she is your relative you should feel at home when she’s your host’; cf. awa(ni)

awen tagiiquq ‘he usually comes’; Awen ungipaqaqanka laluramkenun nunivaget tuqusighaqniluki akmaagutakun. ‘I often tell the white people that we ferment the roseroot in a keg.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 1:90); Unangniilleq tamaana liilightuusaghllaguuq qayughllak awen peleghqutkegkayuk. ‘Hunting for game had many rules and regulations, because there were often mishaps that happened.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 1:130)"

column3: thing that has been used or kept for quite a while

column4: kaaskuma awenralemninnaaaghtunga  ‘when I arrive I’ll stay with my relatives’

other than the usual red fox; Awergha allaghhiinaq yugem tukfighaa. ‘The man is buying all kinds of fur(s).’ (SLI JR. DICT. 40); Nunivak awerghatuuq. Qatelghiituuq, kaviipigtuuq, qenghaghtulguuq, amiklugtuuq, sikigtuuq. ‘The tundra has lots of furbearers. It has lots of white foxes, red foxes, blue foxes, weasels, and squirrels.’ (AANGHHAQ 73)
root; > awillaghate-, awinqute-, awiqe-, awite-, awiyute-

column3: is that so; now I see; now I realize
column4: awi kaasimaa? ‘she got here, didn’t she?’; awi kaasimaa! ‘oh, so she got here!’; Awi whangkutestun akuzing’gannikemken pikayuguziin. Whangkutestun awi ayuqsiin? ‘Oh, you could speak like us? I thought you were never able to do so. I didn’t know you were like us.’ (AYUM. UNGIP. IV:3)"
awillaghatut ‘they all left the area together’
Awilleqa ellngingumalghiit sivumnnelnguut! ‘So, that was them in front of us!’ (SLI JR. DICT 40)"

column3: to make room for something; to reduce the burden on something
column4: awinqutuq ‘he make room, reduced the burden’; awinqutaa ‘he made room by removing it’ / yuuk tagiyan awinqutuq ‘because the man came he made room’; qamiyek usitunaqngayek saghyani awinqutii ‘when the sled was going to have too much of a load he removed his stuff’; angayuqami qepghaghyaghqaan ilangi awinqunnaqneghmeng kayusiitaqii sayaghqiitneng ‘to reduce his parents’ work he helped them with some of it’; usitupigtusi waran whanga awinqunnaqunga ‘you all have too heavy a load so I’m going to get off’

column3: to take out of the way; to remove
column4: Mallungunga ayveghmeng awiqutkamun qagim. ‘I found a dead walrus that had been uncovered by the waves.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 40)

column3: to get out of the way; to take out of the way; to remove
column4: awituq ‘he got out of the way’; awitaa ‘he got it out of the way, he removed it’ / awillaghaatut ‘they all left the area’

aghnequn whaa kenghet qaamyaghqaniiqiit -- kii, awilleqa whaa aqlaghaghhnaqelghiikut ‘they say the electricity is supposed to go off later on today -- oh, so it will be cold in here then’; Sangamek kaamgegken aghipatak? Awituwaq yugneng allaneng ugiighaquten! ‘Why are your boots wet? Maybe you’re having an affair with another man!’ (UNGIPAGHAGH. 9)"
especially in reference to something one wishes were not so; =  agnepa
ayaaguq ‘he went blind’ / ayaamaaq or ayaangaaq ‘he is blind, has become blind’; iyem aqnighneghan ayaastaa ‘eye disease made him blind’

column3: to have difficulty going against the wind; to go against the wind with difficulty
column4: ayaagtuq ‘he went against the wind’; aagken aygughyaghaq ayaaggnapigtuq ‘going against the strong wind from that direction is difficult’; ayaagtem aygumun sukangilliqukut ‘on account of the diffuculty in traveling north against the wind we suffered from going slowly’

column3: blubber used in stove to make the firewood burn better and hotter
column4: nangzeghaghmeng ayaawighpaglukek egllugni kumaghsaqminikek puqlaghqwaagaa ‘she put quite a bit of blubber in her stove when she lit it so it got quite warm’; eglluk uqumeng ayaawighaak quuget kumaragkiighesqelluki ‘she put some blubber in the stove so that the firewood could burn better’

column3: to push off; to push away; to reject; to dislike
column4: ayagtuq ‘he pushed himself away’; ayagaa ‘he pushed her or it away’ / Amik ayagluku uumgaqa. ‘I closed the door by pushing it.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 41)

column3: to train to develop strength; to lift weights

column4: ayagaghtuq ‘he pushed off’; ayagaghtaa ‘he pushed it away’/ yuggaq angyamelnguq sikumeng ayagaghtuq ‘the man in the boat pushed away from the ice’
Chukotkan (R, V&E); ayagaasiq ‘mittens or gloves used to lift weights’

column3: to get into position with the harpoon for striking; to aim harpoon at whale
column4: ayagsiiq ‘he got into position with the harpoon for striking’ / sivuyagtengat ayagsighllaguuq ‘their striker (at the bow) is positioning the harpoon for the strike’

amik pekuutameng ayagsighaa ‘he propped (open) the door with a shovel’; angyaq iggaggluku angwaaghutmeng ayagsiitkelluteng ayagsighaat ‘they propped up the boat leaning it against a paddle which they used as a support’; niillghek ayagsightughlukek aghnaq kiightiiq ‘after propping up the stretching frame the woman is splitting (a walrus hide)’; ayagsiin ‘something used as a prop or support’

column3: push pole; wick adjuster for seal oil lamp; whale harpoon without explosives; pole for skin tent; internal pole of the traditional dome-shaped house
center seal oil-lamp of the tent
implement used to push boat away from ice or ice away from the boat; permanent support in a tent
column4: kangqwaaghmi uunghameng ayagutaqluta angwaaghutmengllu alpagtukut ‘we passed through amid the small pieces of ice floating on the sea using as pushers harpoons and paddles’; angyalek qatmigmeng ayagutaqluni angyaq ayagaa ‘the captain pushed the boat off using a staff as a pushing device’

column3: temporary skin or canvas tent hung up inside a dwelling as a sleeping area to increase warmth at night
to intentionally singe food before eating it; to barbecue; to roast over a fire
column4: ayakaghaa ‘he barbecued it’ / Qawaagmeng ayakaghluku neghtukut. ‘We ate a bird after roasting it over the fire.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 41)
so called from its ease in being melted

column3: to travel (by boat) by pushing off from chunks of ice or pushing ice out of the way
column4: kangqwaaq ayakighaaqluku alpagaghput ‘we passed through it pushing off from the chunks of ice’; ayakighalghiit ayallghitgun igleghtukut ‘we travel through the way where they had pushed the ice away’

column3: to suddenly hit barrier; to encounter a blast of wind
column4: Sikukun ayakilluta kimaawiikut. ‘We ran into pack ice and lost time.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 41)

column3: for wind to blow against it; for winds to blow against each other
column4: anuqmi nalugnaqelghiikut ayakmitaghaakut ‘it was a little hard landing against the wind’

column3: cutting board for use in skin sewing
object or person on which a shaman sits during his shamanistic activity for his flight

column4: ayapeghtuq ‘he leaned his hand on something’; ayapghaa ‘he leaned his hand on it’ /

column3: bone in forearm (either radius or ulna)

column3: to break; to break something off of (it)
column4: ayemkaghaa ‘he broke it’; Savigma nuvuga ayemkaghaqa. ‘I broke the tip of my knife.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 126)
made from oil drippings collected under seal oil lamp, or by slowly cooking seal or whale oil until thick; = ayungkaghaq

column3: to break long thin object to pieces
column4: ayemquq ‘it broke up’; ayemqaa ‘he broke it up’ / esnam tuvaa qagim ayemqaa ‘the waves broke up the shore ice’

column3: to break long thin object to pieces
column4: ayemquq ‘it broke up’; ayemqaa ‘he broke it up’ /

column3: to exercise the legs by walking
column4: ayumiq ayemruugta quunpeng atuqegkaqaat ‘long ago they always engaged in exercise-walking’; iiwleng ayemruugllni yugusiqegnaghtuq (or yugunqeggnaghtuq ?) ‘regular exercise leads to bodily health’

column3: to do something (e.g. fasten something) securely
