column3: for snow to fall in an avalanche on one
deep hollow vibrating sound (like a plane, boat, or thunder in the distance)
column4: levekluguutuq ‘it made a deep hollow sound’

column3: to cut out a pattern; to make a plan (on paper)
column4: liighqaa ‘he cut the pieces for it’ / liighqiiq ‘he cut out pieces for something’

column3: scissors (when used in dual); knife or saw for cutting out pattern
pattern for sewing or otherwise making something

column4: liigi anuqliqestaq kellghiit wiin esghapakaghyaqlegestun ‘the ones leaving by boat knew the wind was picking up, they should’ve watched the weather’; cf. liite-

column3: to recognize; to sense; to understand; to be aware of (it)
column4: liigikaa ‘he recognized it, sensed it’ / liigikiiq ‘he sensed something’; liigikestuq ‘he revealed who he was’; liigiknaghtuq it is understandable’

column3: to be quick-witted; to be shrewd
to fully understand; to learn completely; to master (a subject)
column4: naten igleghtestaqutkek liigilliiqufkek aghtughnanighlleqagken ‘if you fully learn how to start it, you won’t have any problems with it’; maaqellghek liigilliighlukek ayuqagket ‘they have learned how the current runs’; Qineghpeghwaaghaqelghiinga liigilliighyama. ‘I’d scout with binoculars when I got to know (the area).’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 2:156)

column3: to advise; to instruct concerning how to life; teach the rules and ways of life
column4: liilightughtuq ‘he is teaching or advising’; liilightughaa ‘he is teaching him or advising him’ / liilightughaa meghnalisqelluku ‘he advised him to rest’

liilightuusat aapghumiit igam igleghneghi ‘the rules tell about how the school runs’; liilightuusat maliglluteng pinightut ‘it is good to follow rules’; Tamaatum liilightuusaa, eslam, sikum, meghem, maaqellghem,saamllu ilangan natetulnganeng liilluteng wetku ellmegneng mu-ghusaaghteghyuget nukalpigat. ‘Young men had to master the rules concerning weather, ice, sea conditions, currents, and other things they would learn about before they could go out hunting on the ice by themselves.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 1:130)

column3: to always be ready and eager to learn; to be a studious person
column4: liinnaqumalghiit kukriqigalnguut ‘those who are willing to learn don’t have any difficulties’; liinnaqumatmineng ilamineng pillek ‘due to his willingness to learn he knows more than the others’

column3: to become aware; to become conscious; to come to one’s senses
column4: qikmiq suumelghii liipghangluni qimagtuq ‘the dog was berserk, but when it came to its sense, it ran away’; ifkaghluni liipghangyalghiiminguq nevaghmeteftuq ‘he fell and got knocked out, and when he regained conciousness, he realized that he was laying on his back’; cf. liite-
often (or even usually (?)) refers to teaching a song / liisaghtuq ‘he is teaching (a song)’; liisaghaa ‘he is teaching her (a song)’ /

column3: to learn well and remember (of young person); to comprehend well at an early age
column4: uyuqliighngaaghmi liisaghaatmineng neqamikii nallukegkiit ‘even if he is young, he remembers what the others don’t know’

column3: something (especially food) put aside for someone
column4: taana liisaaguq tuguyaqunaan ‘that is being saved for someone, don’t take it’; naagu liisaqa ‘where’s my food that you saved for me’; liisalguyaghtuten aviituq ‘there was something set aside for you, but it’s gone’; = lliisaq
liisimalghii ‘knowledgeable person, wise person, authority on something’

uyavanlluku liisuqaat nalluniilnguq ‘they recognized him from far away because it was easy to tell it was him’; liisuqneghmeng aghtughaat sangutanga ‘they couldn’t recognize what it was’; akuzilghii kinangutanga liisuqaa iglagakun ‘he recognized who was talking with is voice’

column3: to learn; to gain awareness of one's surroundings (said of a young child)
to leave something (usually food) for another
to hesitate to ask again due to having already asked and not received a response; to be tired of asking repeatedly without results
column4: lingghaaq (or lingghayugtuq) ‘he hesitates to ask’ / lingghakaa ‘he hesitates to ask her’

column3: to be uncomfortable; to feel awkward
to send for something; to send someone with instructions; to leave instructions; to place an order for something
column4: lipeghsaghtuq ‘he sent for something’; lipeghsaghaa ‘he sent for it’ / lipeghsaataa ‘he sent for something for her, sent instructions for her’

Yugughtekumtanguq avelghallemta kenlenga liilleqaghput. Llaaghan maaten piyalghiikut, avelghaghaatallemta kenlenga qivghunapigsimaa liisimangilngughni. 'When we becom men we will learn starting from what we missed. Sure enough, now, we regret not learning what we missed out on.' (SIVUQ. UNGIPAGH. 3)"

llaaghanam tawaten apelleghtun taawani aflumi siqineq piituq ‘it was true about they said about when the sun would rise’; aapghaqekangit aangqallguniluki, llaaganam pillepiguftut esghapagyaqeput ‘they say that the ball team was really good, and it was true, they were really good when we watched them’

Aanluni, anigusighaqluni, meghek anigumeng keviimakek. Llaaghanwha itegaan asingi aghimakangi. 'She went out, gathered snow, and filled her water bucked with snow. And consequently the bottoms of her feet got soaked.' (UNGIPAGHAGH. 9); Llaaghanwha aghnaghaam nagaquumakanga. Taagken aanumalghii. Llaaghanwha aghnaghaq palaghhaghmeng  iyataneghmini neghaqelghii. ‘And then the girl listened to him. After that he went out.  And then whenever the girl got too hungry she would eat.’ (UNGAZ. UNGIP. 72)"

expresses satisfaction for having made a good choice in one’s actions; llaaghinaan angyaamaanga, llaaghanwha neqetukut ‘good thing I went boating, we got food’; llaaghinaan apeghtughilghiit nagataqaput ‘good thing we listen to them teaching’; cf. llaaghan"

column3: muscular person; person with large muscles
column4: yuget iknaqughikat llaaghwneghet ‘men who became strong, have very large muscles’; mataghsalghiimi llaaghwnepiguftuq ‘when he took off his chothes, he turned out to have large muscles’

column3: the extremities of the body of a whale, person, etc.
looks as if; looks like; sounds like; apparently
column4: Mangteghapigit taagantusaghpetut, llangaqa maaken aaftaghaghluteng taagavek. ‘Their traditional houses were out that way, and it seems like that were separated from here.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 1:10); Taana llangaqa eghqwaaq nangllegsiisiiguq ama igamsiqayugusiiguq. ‘Apparently that ceremony of making offerings was to show one’s compassion and thankfulness.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 1:206)"

column3: it turns out; on the contrary
to decorate or be decorated; to sew or be sewn with a fancy design
column4: kaamgek ulimaaghqek llevlutek ayuquk ‘the skinboots she made have a fancy design’; ughnegegni llevlukek kakiiqaak ‘she is sewing them with a fancy design’

column3: to put fancy handywork on garment
to place; to put; to set
column4: llii ‘he put it (somewhere)’ / navek llizigu? ‘where did you put it?’

column3: to become a certain way; to start living in a certain place
column4: lliightuq or lliighaa ‘he became (thus)’ / ‘Sivuqamun lliightuq ‘she started living in Gambell’; Elpeklu tawaten lliighnaquten whangkutestun. ‘And you are going to become like us.’ (AYUM. UNGIP. II 37); Taam kingunganeng elngaatall aghveghniiq akuzisaghanguq qafsin'ggaawaqluni lliightuq. ‘After that the issue of whale hunting was discussed prominently, and reached the point that only a few could be taken. (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 2:34); Iwerngaqun herder-ngughsimaamta money-ngiighhaghmeng ilaluta lliighiinkut. ‘But when we became herders it became such that we were paid with a little bit of money.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 2:82)

column3: piece of skin that has been cut out
something (especially food) put aside for someone
to flatten the surface of something
column4: liivneqegsaghluku nuna tiintat nekegteki ‘flatten the ground and set up the tent’
uyghagem qaaynga lliivneqegtaq llivikigu ‘put something on the flat top surface of that rock’

column3: to command to go somewhere; to send (a person) somewhere; to chase away (an animal)
column4: apeghtughaaghluku taaqsamigu llilaghaa ‘after he taught him thoroughly, he sent him out’; nuuk unaksaghqaq taaga llilaghaa ‘he chased away the surfaced seal that was to have been caught’

column3: to have more than what is needed
column4: pinaqneghutmeggneng quunpeng llileghluteng ayuqaqut ‘because of their aggressiveness, they always have more than what they need’

column3: something stored away for the future
to place something somewhere and forget where it was placed; to misplace
column4: llineghllugtaa ‘he misplaced it’ / igani llineghlluglluki ivanghiighutii ‘having forgotten where she placed her book she looked all over for it’; iganka navek llineghllugsimaanka ‘I have misplaced my book’

column3: with only moderate strength, tension or effort; lightly
column4: iighsuutet wiin llinghinaghmeng nengteki ‘stretch the pulley only slightly (for now)’
lliivghaa yugem taghnughhani tuqukaq ‘the man buried his dead child’
may be used in the dual, llivelghak, for one shelf

column3: to pay; to place something on (it); to get even with (him)
column4: llivikaa ‘he paid him’, ‘he put something on it’, or ‘he got even with him’ / Asengenka qamaglluki llivikanka. ‘I paid all my bills.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 34); Piitesghaghmeng llivikagka tuqukam salngagkek. ‘He put flowers on the coffin of the one who died.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 86)

column3: to use a sling as in hunting
column4: lluuguq ‘he used a sling’; lluugaa ‘he used a sling against it (target, game animal)’ / lluuluku ‘(after) using a sling on it’
used in the dual, lluuk, for one sling

column3: Lorino in Chukotka (north of main (Central Siberian) Yupik area)

column4: literally, ‘time of hunting with a sling’; also given in various sources as March, March-April, and May
lluuquyaghluni lluukegkani tugullghisimakanga ‘he went out hunging with a sling, and he didn’t retrieve what he caught with his sling’

column3: Shlokovik Pt. on St. Lawrence Is.
to go bird-hunting with a sling
column4: ugavek sukilpaanun lluuquyaq qawiimalghii ‘the person who went hunting with a sling for auklets, caught a lot of birds’; lluuquyaghluni lluukengumalghii ‘he went hunting with a sling and caught something’

column3: to fix something up; to make something or someone look nice; to smooth out; to make presentable
column4: luufsaghtuq ‘he fixed himself up’; luufsaghaa ‘he fixed it up’ /

column3: edge of a large expanse of shorefast or moving ice
column4: dual, luughek, used for one such edge; see item 33 on list in Oozeva et al. 2004

Amen nunamnun aglaghnaanghitunga. Luuraqlu nunamnun kaaskuma ugima tuqulleqanga. ‘See, I won't go to my hometown. It might be that if I go home, my husband will kill me.’ (UNGIPAGH. 11); Atkugmeng kelqegkaalghiinga, allightemeng, ayapghaatameng luuraq naalkuskumta aasightuusighqameng. ‘I brought a parka, boot insulation and mittens so that in case we find people, we can dress them.’ (PANGEGH. 54)"

column3: to run out of or finish up something quickly; to purposely leave none for others
column4: nengiisaghqaayalghii tugulaamakangat ilateng maaghaghlluki ‘he was supposed to get a share, but they all took a lot and they didn’t leave any for him’
from Saturday being the seventh day of the week

column3: to whip until thick and/or fluffy; to set something upright
column4: eslevaganeghmeggni aghnat maakesniiqiit igughhneghata ‘when women make a dish out of salmon-eggs, they say that they whip it with seal oil until it thickens to the right consistency’

column3: to be the only two remaining
column4: maalghuggaaghtuk ‘they’ve become the only two left’

the word maalghuk is a dual, but the singular, maalghu, can also occur as in: tightughyaqminiki Uuleghmiit taakut maalghu sangwaa ataasiq laluramketillegraak uugtaataqayuk Pedersen-kun. ‘When he read them [the letters] he observed that one, maybe two. of those Uelen people could handle English having gone onboard with [Capt.] Pedersen.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 3:144); also, the plural, maalghut, can occur as in: Maalghut usikaataghaput ataasikun quyngikun, 150 pound-et coal-et ataasit. ‘We would transport two 150-pound apiece lots of coal with one reindeer [trip].’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 2:76); cf. maaghraghvinlek

column3: to get trapped in ice when boating
column4: maallgusaaghiisi taglaghtuullghaasi ‘be careful, don’t get trapped (by the ice), come to land now’; angyannguq unga maallgusimii ‘they say the boat is closed in by ice out there’

column3: despite things being the way they are; anyway; serves him right!; at last
column4: Piiqegkenka panigenka, maalliqun piniqsaliighllagaanga qavngaq ugumikeghllaglunga. ‘I tell my daughters that despite those things at last she feels quite positive towards me (now) whereas she once despised me.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 3:90); Pimakanga, ""Maalliqun whanga piiqaghhnaaghyukaghpenga."" Ii, aghuliiqaghlluni uutqaghtuq. ‘He said, “ha-ha, you didn’t catch me!’ But then it stopped and turned back!’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 3:172)"

column3: to heal (of wound); to close over
column4: maamuq or maamaa ‘it healed’ / kililqa maamuq ‘my cut healed’; maamtaa ‘he closed it in’; Kililqa itegamnilnguq maamumaaq. ‘The cut on my foot has healed.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 89); Segevneq sikumelnguq maamaquq. ‘The crack in the ice is freezing over.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 89)

column3: to fix temporarily or in a make-shift way
column4: qamiyngiilluni unaghsimeng teggusighlukek maamghulukek tagisiqumakek ‘when his sled broke, he used a stick for a make-shift repair for it, and then brought it home’; ayemellghet maamghuluki igleghtuq ‘he fixed the broken parts and left’

column3: to become or make thinner, narrower or calmer
column4: maamkelliiq ‘it got thinner, narrower or calmer’; maamkellii ‘he made it thinner, narrower or calmer’ /

column3: dressing for wounds; something that helps a wound to heal

column4: taghnughhaat mangteghamun mayughtuullaataghtut; maamtawhanguq ineghtiit ‘ the children climbd up onto the house again; again they were told not to do that’

maamtuuq ‘it is thick or wide’ / maamtuqaq ‘thick or wide thing’; Ayveghem amiirii kiightellghilluteng maamtuqat. ‘Unsplit walrus hide is quite thick.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 89); Angyanghitukut sallek maamtupigtuq. ‘We didn’t go hunting because the young ice was too wide.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 89)

column3: this one; this kind; this one here; on to the next part; and then
to try to soothe (a crying baby)
to try to stop a child from crying
column4: maangnaqim taghnughhateng kevgaaghumiita ilagaataqegkangit ‘they carry them and sing to the children when they are crying to help them stop crying’; maangniqem sayaghqani pinghitii ‘he was trying to stop a child from crying, so he didn’t do what he had been going to do’; cf. mangigh-

column3: to come here (to this general area)
column4: Maapiighaatalleghput liisimakaqa. Maapiluta aglaghaqluta piighaataqani. ‘I remember how we’d go there and come here. We used to go there and come here again.’  (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 3:66)

column3: to drain out; to ooze; to flow; to run (of liquids)
column4: maaquq ‘it flowed or oozed out’ / maaqestaa ‘he let it flow, drained it’
used in the dual, maaqellghek, for the current

column3: ocean current flowing from southwest to northeast
column4: used in the dual, maaqneghek, for the current; Upenghami maaqneghek iknaquughqaaghllakayugek. ‘In springtime the (north) current gets very strong.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 90)

column3: to drift by with the current; for the current to carry one away (as in a boat)
column4: maaqutaa ‘it (the current) carried it or him away’

column3: to be penetrated by the cold air or wind
column4: aatkii ugmestaaghhaat sukalluni maastaa ‘his clothing was so thin that it was quickly penetrated by the wind’

column3: a short while ago; just now; right around here
the same as a while ago
now you see!; there you have it!; I told you so!; I just told you
a little while from now; shortly
column4: Tengegkayuget maateqwaaqun kaallequt. ‘The airplane will arrive in a little while.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 90)

column3: to suddenly clear up after blizzard
column4: maatkaghyalghiimi uga mangteghatlu aliightut ‘when it suddenly cleared up, the houses appeared’; llaaghinaan maatkaqaghaa, igleghneqa naallghutaqa ‘good thing it cleared up as I can now correct my course’
maatneghtuq ‘it is warm’ / maatneghtaa ‘he warmed it’

column3: bark of tree; hollow end of walrus tusk

column4: menga ‘his voice’; … tawaten mem taghtughtaqegkanga, piiqegkangat “Kii, aghnaghaghhaq una igamsiqanaghhalek nangllegtapigta” ‘… the voice awakened her as they were saying, “My goodness! How grateful we should be for her kindness.”’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 3:198); cf. nepiiq

An'giisimaluki igaghvigem manughaani, melugutaqun'nguq maghhuurkameng, … aqumuulluteng ilangi. ‘When they were outside taking a break in front of the school, they were smoking Russian tobacco, … sitting there, some of them.‘ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 2:208)

column3: to invite to the dance floor during a particular indigenous Eskimo dance event held yearly followed by a gift exchange
gift exchange ceremony after a particular Eskimo dance event held yearly
column4: involves bringing a cross-cousin to the floor to dance
maghqatuq ‘it locked up’ or ‘he locked up’; maghqataa ‘he locked it up’ / maghqatngaaq ‘it is locked up, closed for the day (business or office)’
dual, maghqatusik, used for one lock; Mangteghaghput maghqatusilighaqa amigakun. ‘I put a padlock on the door of our house.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 95)

column3: to tuck lower part of face in one's garments
column4: done to ward off the cold or because of shyness or sadness; Ilangani ghhuunnemta maghuyugtaqukut. ‘Sometime when we are cold we tuck our faces inside our coats.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 90)

column3: food that is eaten first; first course at a meal
column4: neghnaqelghiini sivukluki neghyaghqat maghyaghqelliitmeng nalighmen sivullughquutmeng aatqelghiit ‘at meal time, food that is eaten first is called “lead course” or “first course”’
maghyaghqughtuq ‘he lead’; maghyaghqughii ‘he lead them’ / Elpek liisimakan tuma, maghyaghqughqut. ‘You know the wqay, so go ahead and lead us.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 46)

column3: towline of sled going all the way to the lead dog
column4: maghyaghqughsiin qikmiin kepumakanga ‘his dogs cut the towline’
Neghnam aghnaanghan makaatangan asingi eslevagmeng imaqeftut. ‘Under the female crab’s sack there were eggs.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 91)
makaa ‘he put a diaper on him’

column3: to stand up; to get up; to stand (it) upright
column4: maketuq ‘he got up’; maketaa ‘he put it upright’ / maketen ‘get up!’; cf. makiga-

column3: to be in an upright or erect state or condition
column4: makigaaq ‘it is upright’ / kiti nevaan ifkaghtekuvgu makigaghmi tekillequq ‘if you drop a cat upside down, it will land upright’; makigaan lligu ulleghnayukan ‘place it upright in case it falls’; cf. makete-

column3: to gnaw on a bone with meat attached to it
column4: makightuq ‘he or it gnawed on something’; makighaa ‘he or it gnawed on it’ / Neghsam tulimakek maalghuk makighagka. ‘I ate the meat from two seal ribs.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 91)

column3: to split following the grain (of wood)
column4: qamiskama suqaghneghaqaa makiighyan atughhneghitaqa ‘when the runner for my sled to-be started to split I didn’t use it’; sayugagma esnekek makiighaqeftuk ‘the rim of my drum happens to be splitting’

column3: bone from which meat has all been picked or gnawed

column4: its skin is used for boot soles and its face is somewhat reddish; cf. maklak

column3: to place one’s tail between ones legs

column4: used in the plural, maklagut, for the intestines of one seal;  Maklagut saghnaaqsaqangit qaliiluki ama aghsughtaaluki. ‘People used to save bearded seal intestines for making raincoats or bleached gut wind jackets.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 91)

… maklawaaghem  tugumaa.  Nenglunga inga, meghem esnenganituq.  Nunaaghem  aghnaa qerngughsimaa maklawaaghem. ‘… the caterpillar had taken her. Its house was there by the shore of the sea. The caterpillar had gathered [into captivity] the women of the camp.’ (MATERIALY 443);literally, 'pretend bearded seal, thing like a bearded seal'; cf. similar idiom in Central Yup’ik, where ‘caterpillar’ is u!u!uaq from Inupiaq u!$uk ‘bearded seal’ (or an obsolete Yupik cognate thereof);

column3: to pull in a rope hand-over-hand or check to net this way; to shinny up or down a rope or pole; to get eggs on a cliff down on a rope
column4: maklighaaq ‘he shinnied up or down; he checked a net’ / maklighaghaa ‘he shinnied up or down it; he checked it’

column3: to butcher or otherwise prepare bearded seal
intermediate level of atmosphere, without much air
surface of sea ice covered with small smooth bumps, suitable for hunting and traveling but causing boat and sled to vibrate when pulled across it
column4: see item 34 on list in Oozeva et al. 2004

column3: to peel; to peel (off); to shed covering, skin, etc.; to strip off skin or the like
column4: makregtuq ‘it peeled or peeled off; its peel came off; it shed its covering’ / makregtaa ‘he peeled it’; makregutuq ‘he peeled something’; Piineluk makregtuq mangtegham minglenganeng. ‘ The old paint is peeling off from the walls of the old house.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 91); cf. makete-

column3: to cause elevated abrasions; to scrape one’s skin on something
to have a difficult time doing something
to have a hard time doing something; to be unable to do something difficult
column4: kaasaqegka unangneghmeng makruughiiqeftuq nuugllagmi imani ‘when I got to him, he was having a hard time getting a seal even though there were so many’; makruughiyama qenwat iilqayugtunga ‘when I couldn’t do it, I finally gave up’

column3: to show no sign of living presence; to be quiet and still
column4: nunaaghmelgnguut naghughtaput angyameng maksulqaghhiilnguut entaqun qavaatnguut ‘the people at the camp that we passed by in the boat showed no sign of their presence, probably all being asleep’; nunavaget maksulqaghhiilnguut piyaqeput tuqukaperugwaaghet ‘the still, quiet herd of walrus on ice that we came to turned out to be all dead’

column3: to unharness, unfasten, or otherwise undo dogs
column4: makughqughtuq ‘he undid the dogs’; makughqughii ‘he undid them’ /

column3: shed fur or hair of animal
column4: qikmimta makugnegha mallaaghutuq ilunganilnguq ‘our dog’s hair that has been shedd is becoming messy  being inside (the house)’; teghigluget aqsamelluteng makugtaqelghiit enkaam makugneghtuumaghmeng aanaqut ‘baby bearded seals shed when they are in the womb still, so the shed hair comes out with the baby’

column3: to shed; to moult; to slip out of a loop which holds one
column4: makugtuq ‘it shed; it slipped out’; makugtaa ‘he undid it (dog)’ / qikmiq makugutuq ‘the dog got loose, slipped out of its collar and tether’; Qimugsineng kaallunga qikmima qaghlungi makughqughanka. ‘After arriving from driving the dogs I slipped off my dogs’ harnesses.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 92); Unaaq elngaatall qilak makugaghtaa. ‘The clouds suddenly moved away this morning.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 92)
malghik ‘pair of twins’; malghikaqa ‘he is my twin’

column3: to act in pairs; to divide in two
column4: malghughqelluteng angyaghtut ‘they divided up the boating crew into two’

used with a plural ending and therefore realized as malghugneghet, malghugneghneng, etc.; used to indicate two things, when the noun for that thing is used in the plural or dual even for a single entitity, or to indicate two groups (such as families), thus: Malghugneghet siifluki unkuset ataasikaghsimalghiit kaviighmeng. ‘Setting two traps, [they] caught [one] fox.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 151; note that dual, unkusek, is used for one ‘trap’); Taakwagun, qamiyet malghugneghet, … ‘[For that first trip here] two sleds [were used], …’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 2:156; note that dual, qamiyek, is used for one ‘sled’); Taakut pughileghmelnguut Agaankutlu, Anagutaankutlu malghugneghet. ‘Only two families were staying permanently at Southwest Cape, Agaq and family, and  Anagutaq and family.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 2:162)

column3: to act on things twice or two at a time
column4: malghukaghtaan tunqughii ‘he gave them out two at a time’; malghukaghsimaaq kaviighmeng ‘he caught two foxes’
malghukliiq ‘he is undecided’ / malghuklitkaa ‘he is undecided about it’

column3: each of two shares given separately (when one given for both would have sufficed)

type of edible seashore life orange in color with yellow dots

to loose (part of) outer layer of skin through rubbing or the like
outer layer of skin or hide
outer layer of skin or hide

also used in Chukotka; Qawaagpagem tengunnaqumakanga unglutminun mankingiighhaq. ‘The giant bird was going to fly off to its nest with the little monkey.’ (AANGHHAQ 82)

cf. mangteghaq; used in the plural, mangtaaghet, for one nest (with eggs); Mangtaaghhaat nalluniighiit takwaaghaataghnaluki, aflengaknalukillu. ‘They put a marker at the little nest so that they could come see it and watch over it.’ (PIYAA. 7)

column3: thin skin from whale mouth area

column4: Aghveghem mangtaga qamaglluku pilagaat. ‘They cut all the skin off the whale.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 95)

column3: to make a house for; to reassemble a house (in fall after its parts have been aired out)
traditional dome-shaped Chukchi-style house with walrus skin roofing held in place by rocks hanging from the edge; yaranga
column4: this term is used to distinguish the traditional Chukchi-style Eskimo house from a modern house; this style of house replaced the earlier semi-subterranean house (nenglu) and was itself replaced by  the Euro-American style frame house

this term is used to refer to the traditional Chukchi-style Eskimo dome-shaped house with walrus skin cover held down with rock weights hanging from the edges , called ‘yaranga’ in Russian, or to a modern house, as opposed to the earlier semi-subterranean house, nenglu; the term mangteghapik is used to distinguish the traditional Chukchi style house from a modern house; = mengteghaq

column3: summer house (often makeshift, of walrus hide)

column4: mangteghiightuq ‘he built a house’; manteghiighaa ‘he built a house for him’ /

column3: site of former house or settlement; house ruins
to surface or show the back when beginning to dive deeply (of whale)
column4: piigluku aghveq mangughsan aghveqaa ‘they followed the whale and when it was starting down for a deep dive, he struck it’

column3: to lose some of the skin from the back (of a whale)

column3: dirt caked up on some part of one’s body

column4: mangzighhuq ‘it gnawed’; mangzighhaa ‘it gnawed on it’ / mangzighhelleq ‘gnawed spot’

also used in Chukotka; Enkaam piniqnaanghitaghsi Kiyaghneq piniqumaluku mani. ‘Also, you won’t love God by loving money.’ (Matthew 6.24); Una qepghaqaq allgeqaaguq maningyama grant-meng …. ‘This project began when I received funds from a grant ….’ (UNGIPAGHAGH. xv)
maniiq ‘he moved close to something’; manii ‘he moved close to it’ / cf.  maniguute-, maniighaghte-

manigughaa ‘he soothed her’ / manigughiiq ‘he soothed someone’; cf. mangsingugh-

manigniightuq ‘he looked for eggs’; manigtuq ‘he collected eggs’; maniliightuq ‘he cooked eggs’; manigtughtuq ‘he ate eggs’

column4: used in the dual, manilghutak, for one wallet

used in the plural, manitet, for one fortification; akingani agani manitet taaganniiqsaghiit ‘they say that there used to be fortifications south of the village’

column3: fixed protective shield (as used in warfare)
column4: used in the plural, manitat, for one such shield

column3: front; chest and neck area right below one’s face

maqaaghtuq or maqaaghtaa ‘he or it warmed up’ / siqineq maqaaghtaqaa ‘the sun is getting warm (as in spring)’
Amim qaayngakun qakmagun eslataakun maqaasghightuutkaqegkangit. ‘They’d put it as insulation over the surface of the skin (of the house) out there.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 3:104)

maqaghquq he dressed warmly; maqaghqaa he dressed her warmly /

iipagmi qalmesam maqallangi qiighninnaghllaget igleghlleghhiini ‘in extreme low tide the algae on the rocks is really slippery when one walks on it’; kiiwem esnekek maqallaghllaguftuq ‘the beach of the river turned out to have a lot of algae’

column4: used in the dual, maqak, for one jacket

device used in making a liquid flow; milk-pail

Maknik Lagoon on St. Lawrence Is.
column4: or Maqneghem Naayvaa; see Map 6 in Appendices

column3: for weather to warm up in spring

to warm oneself by stove or other heat source
column4: masighaghtuq ‘he warmed up’; masighaghaa ‘he warmed it up’ / cf. masa-

column3: St. Lawrence Island / Siberian Yupik Eskimo or Naukan Yupik Eskimo; as a particle: originally; genuinely; very; fully; sure thing; it’s alright; just fine
column4: Sivuughaqestaghngaamkun quyngiqa naavyighnayukan pingayiitaqa. ""Masingka legan itagnalghii!"" ‘Even though I hesitated thinking that my reindeer might be overwhelmed I did put the third one on it. “Sure thing; let’s do it; it will be fine”, (I said). (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 2:78); Kiyaghsimaaq Qigimi yuuk neqengyuqaq. Kiigunneghagu qayaghtuneghmini unakaqegkanga masingka uksumi naamatkaghqaq neqa. ‘There lived man, a good provider, in Qigi. Every summer he went out hunting and sure enough he’d get food sufficient for the winter.’ (UNGIPAGHAGH. 141); Uyughani pilaataghaa, ""Naqamllu whaa elpek pengegniighutaaten. Masingka nemetwhayaaghtaaten."" ‘She said to her younger brother, “You are no longer someone who one must worry about. You’ve gotten so that you can stay on your own just fine now.”’ (UNGIPAGH. 162)"

column3: to succeed at what one is doing; to do well; to prosper
column4: Yuget aghvengneghmeggni masinkataqut nunaaghet. ‘Whenever the people catch a whale, the village does well.’ (AANHHAQ 30)

Meghmun ateghyalghiimi teghhanun pesughyukangghituq. Masisu esghaamakanga aga yuggaq tallileklu ighuleklu takestaaghhaghmeng naqam yugusii aangepiglleghhii. ‘He got to the bottom of the sea and had no difficulty breathing. Moreover [there] he saw a little person with long arms and legs and a big torso.’ (UNGIPAGHAGH. 93); = maasisu

column3: to become skinny; to get thin; become emaciated
column4: neghqutkiillghem qikmiput taawa maslegtuutut ‘our dogs are getting skinny because we don’t have food for them’; iilqeghllagem qenwat maslegtuq ‘he’s getting thin, because he’s been so depressed’; Uukat kinenghhat, iwhani piniipigtut September-em uukaghtii. Kineghllagtestegpenaki qeghaataqelghiit eghqwaaghutkaghqaaluki. Aamta sivuliit August-em pingi maslekanighaqut. ‘September is best for drying cod. Before they get too dry they’d be bundled and stored. The first ones, those of August, would shrivel up.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 1:92)

column3: to get or go right to or on the edge
column4: masughluku neghqwaagha ggaaygem uuupunnakek ‘let him cut it right on the edge of the shoulder blade’

column3: core of tusk, bone or root

column4: mataawiiq ‘he had a hard time’ / mataawitkaa ‘he had a hard time over it’; mekelghiighhaam unangkani mataawisimaagu tuguneghmeng; kitum angyanun tugusqelligu ‘the boy was having a hard time retrieving the seal he’d caught; he should have had someone in a neighboring boat retrieve it’
mataghtuq ‘he took off his parka or coat, or his clothes’; mataghngaaq ‘he is without a parka or coat, undressed’; mataghmi aanuq ‘he went outside without a coat’"
aqlagha mataghhwaaghvigituq ‘there’s no way to get by dressing lightly  in the cold’; kiigmi mataghhwaaq itagnaghtuq ‘dressing lightly in the summer is fine’

column4: mataghquq ‘he removed his (own) outer clothing’ or ‘he stripped’; mataghqaa ‘he removed his (another’s) outer clothing’ or ‘he stripped him’ /

to tire; to lose fragrance, taste or zest
short boot with fold over insole

Mayeraaghpagem tuguluku naasquminun qaakumakanga. ‘The giant grabbed him and put him up on his head.’ (YUGG. Mayer. 13)
ikani mayiimi pegnem qaygeghtunga ‘I barely got to the top at the slope south of here’; Qayillghet mayiingat iggagrukegtepigtuq ‘the slope at Qayilleq is steep’; cf. mayugh-
mayleghuklukek ullghitagni guutelleghqakek unisimakek ‘he didn’t think his snowmachine would start, so he left it’

pile; heap; sternpost of boat; bowpost of boat

column3: to drink (any beverage, especially one that is cool); to drink an alcoholic beverage

column4: also used in the dual, meghaak, for one such hole

small area of open water in sea ice where one can sit and watch for seals; childhood; infancy
column4: used in the dual, meghhaak, for one such area; see item 98 on list in Oozeva et al. 2004; the meaning ‘childhood, infancy’ is said to be from the child’s being in a fluid state of development; ighneni meghhaaneng peghqigsaqaa unangniighmeng ‘he taught his son how to hunt since his childhood’; ima meghhaatanganeng ‘since infancy’

column3: large area of open water; polynya
column4: used in the dual, meghllagek, for one such area
Meghnaaliiqluta naayghamun mayughtukut. ‘We rested several times as we climbed the mountain.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 89)

column3: to water; to sprinkle water on (it); for water to appear on ice; to splash water on (it); to apply water to (it)
column4: meghqaa ‘he applied to or splashed water on it’ /

column3: to be transparent; to be clear
column4: nulughyalghiinga teghhani sama kayumeng esghaatunga qayughllak meq meghraakegtepiglleghhii ‘when I was fishing with a hook and line I saw a fish near the bottom because the water was very clear’

column3: to be very light in color; to be transparent

column3: to give a drink to a person or animal (dog usually)
column4: meghsii ‘he gave him or it a drink’ /
meghtaghtuq ‘he fetched water’ / meghtaataa ‘he fetched water for her’; meghtaghvikaa ‘he fetched water from it, it’s the place where he got water’
also meghuta; also used in the dual, meghutek or meghutak, for one such item
used in the dual, meghutlugek, for one empty can
Qikmighhiinaghhaa meghyaghqughtenga Elqwaaghqum aapqaqaa kaatkaq. ‘According to Elqwaaqu, only his lead dog made it back.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 3:64)

column3: caring deeply; valuing; holding as important
column4: megnukaa ‘he cares deeply for him/it’; megnunaghtuq ‘it is important, it is valuable’; avaqutani megnukepiglluku anglistekaa ‘he raised his child caring deeply for him’; megnukumtaani saghyat kagpagii ‘he packed his important belongings’"

column3: to be important; to be valued; to be treasured
column4: megnunaghtuq ‘it is important’ / megnunaghtuq qayughllak naamneng aatquq ‘she is treasured since she has my mother’s name’; … unguvalleq megnunaghataghaghtuq neqmeng, yugusiqlu megnunaghataghaghtuq aatkaneng. ‘… life itself is more important than food, and the body is more important than clothing.’ (Matthew 6.25)

column3: to smooth out or make even  with one’s teeth
column4: Ang, piighhangllaa. Nuvagsukaghpenaan mekegraghyukaghpenaan. 'Yes, braid [some thread], but don't even make a move toward moistening the strands with saliva or smoothing them out with your teeth.' (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 3:208)

column3: to scrape off; to peel off; to strip off
column4: maklagem qilungan qaayngi mekegtii neghyaghqaaluki ‘she scraped off the outer layer of a bearded seal’s intestines for eating’; kitum gginan mekegtagu? ‘who scraped (scratched) your face?’

mekelghiighhaq ‘little boy’; mekelghiighet ‘boys’; Mekelghiighhaamallemni esghapagllakaqegkegka Ungaziinkuk Sivuqaankuk naavghullutek ayuqelghiik. ‘When I was a little boy I used to see Chaplino and Gambell people going back and forth.’ (PANGEGH. 17)

column3: to become smaller; to make smaller; to alter (by making smaller) in sewing
column4: mekelliiq ‘it is getting smaller; mekellii he is making it smaller’ /

column3: strip of fabric on a sail which can be tied to shorten the sail

column4: mekestaaghmeng pilguunga ‘I have a small one’; mekestaaghuuq nanughtaa ‘the polar bear he got was a small one’; = mekestaaghhaq
tiintat sivulighneng mekitkughmetut ‘the tent is somewhat smaller than the first one’

column3: walrus with long tusks that touch or cross at the tips
to come into indistinct view through darkness, mist, fog, etc.

column4: also used in the dual, melghutak, for one container

column3: to send word; to pass the word
column4: panigmikun meliqaa ‘she sent word by her daughter’

kiiwhken Sivungameng meliqimalghii aqfaaghtesqelluni ‘he (from Savoonga) sent someone (to Gambell) for someone to come get him’; apeghiiqufsi meliqilghaasi aqfalleqamsi ‘when you (all) are finished, have someone come (and tell me) and I’ll get you’

qepghaallghiit umiilgita sagiqiganniluki melitaqumakangi ‘the foreman spoke harshly to his workers becasue they weren’t putting enough effort into their work’; angyalgita nunmaagitneng melitaqaqii awen ‘their captain often spoke harshly to them because of their slowness’

column3: to plug; to cover an opening
column4: mellaa ‘he plugged it’ / melliiguq ‘he plugged an opening’; mellulleqaa ‘he will plug it’
Qergesem mellutaa igaghqwaaq umuqaq apengtaqa aangyan. ‘I folded over the cardboard window covering  because it was [too] big.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 31)
Apayepayiiq uteghniimalghii nguuyngaaghaghmun.  Melnguq nunmaawhtapagem kinguliiluni kaasimalghii. ‘The spider returned to the fly’s house. Because the beetle dallied he returned last.’ (SULUWET 33)

column3: to remove fur or body hair from skin; to lose fur

to be bald; to have one’s lost hair
to be bald; to have one’s lost hair
feather or fur that has been strewn over an area

column3: to be fledged; to become covered with hair
shaggy or long-haired dog; arctic loon (Gavia arctica)
column4: Qikmighaghhaghnguq melqupagraaghhaq tagiiq naken tamaaken. ‘A shaggy puppy came on the scene.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 2:208)
melqwa or melqwi ‘its fur, its hair’

column3: to suck; to smoke; to bite (of mosquito)
column4: melugtuq ‘he sucked, smoked’; melugaa ‘he smoked or sucked it’ / sugukelingiighem melugaa ‘the mosquito bit him (literally, sucked him (i.e., his blood)’)
melugraghtuq ‘he kept sucking something’; melugraghaa ‘he kept sucking it’ /
said to be so called from the sucking action they make when touched

used in the ablative-modalis as indefinite object of the verb taaqe- ‘to finish’: Meghumalghii taagken.  Meneghmeng taaqluni tamaani yuvghiighluni esghapagluni aanumalghii. ‘Then he drank. After he finished drinking he went outside there to look and check on things.’ (KALLAG. 10); see also discussion of -neq1 in the postbase section

column3: noise of a lot of people together
column4: mengelghat nagaqughluki takwaaput ‘we heard a lot of people talking and we went to them’; neghuullghiit qerngaghllagmeng mengelghangat seghleghllaguuq ‘a large group was eating, and the noise they made was bad’

column3: for people to talk in a way such that they cannot be understood due to distance, noice, etc.
column4: naken mengelghataqat? ‘where is all the talking coming from?’

column3: to babble (of baby); to mumble; to make non-speech vocal sounds
vocal but non-speech sound(s); babbling; mumbling
to feel left out when one doesn’t receive anything from someone
column4: ellmi tuuneghinniluni menghuluni nengaamalghii ‘she thought she didn’t get anything, so she felt left out and stalked off’; ilangi yugem menghuketaghaqluteng ayuqut ‘some people are sensitive about being left out’

column3: to be such as to cause one to feel an obligation to act (especially, to render aid)
to tire of being pestered by (him)
column4: Amenam aglaghluni, iitqiinaghluni anenghaghhani qinuyugtaa ughluvghaangliisqelluku, weni qinuyugtaa. Qenwat anengaghhaan mengilegyagulluku amenam yataaghqutuq. ‘Then she went home, and as soon as she came in she started pestering her brother to make a bow. Finally her brother got tired of being pestered and got ready (to make the bow).’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 3:204)

column3: to feel obliged (due to being cajoled, having one’s pity aroused, etc.) to act
column4: ighneghhaghmi mengilegyugsatni maligtesqelluni qenwat qepghaqani peglluku pimalghii ‘when his son cajoled him, asking him (the father) to go with him, he (the father) finally left his work and did (as requested)’

column3: to melt snow or ice for water
column4: mengllaghtuq ‘he melted snow or ice for water’; mengllaghaa ‘he melted it for water’ or ‘he melted snow or ice to make water for her’ /

column3: to pop gum while chewing it
column4: mengqughtafqaavek ‘stop popping your gum while you chew’
mengqughuutuq ‘it made a popping sound’; mengqughuutaa ‘he made a popping sound with it’; ‘ he popped it’ /

column3: goose bump; feather stem on birdskin
column4: mengqwi ‘his goose bumps’; leghlleq ghhiitaqaqa mengqughtupigtuq ‘the goose I plucked has a lot of feather stems’

Chukotkan primarily;  this term is used to refer to the traditional Chukchi-style Eskimo dome-shaped house with walrus skin cover held down with rock weights hanging from the edges , called ‘yaranga’ in Russian, or to a modern house, as opposed to the earlier semi-subterranean house, nenglu; the term mengteghapik is used to distinguish the traditional Chukchi style house from a modern house; Yugem pimakangi:  "Aghnani ukughsi,  iightingnga. Maklawaaq tuquskumkun, mengteghaghpesinun aglaghllequsi." ‘The man said to them, “You women, hide yourselves. When I kill the caterpillar you will all return to your houses.”’ (MATERIALY 444); = mangteghaq

column3: to make vocal sounds repeatedly but intermitently
column4: sangwaa mengwaagtaghta? ‘what is making those vocal sounds?’

column3: to hear vocal sounds repeatedly but intermitently
column4: nunavak uglaneghmini repall mengwaaglluni lliiqayuk ‘when a herd of walrus on ice is numerous, vocal sounds can be heard on and off’

column3: moaning; groaning; vocal but non-speech sound(s); unintelligible voices heard in the distance
to attract unwanted spirits especially from the ocean by making excessive noise
unwanted spirit attracted by excessive noise

column4: menutuuq ‘it was forceful’ / akuziiq menutuluni ‘he spoke loudly’; nuna aaghhaghtuq menutuluni ‘the earthquake was strong’

column3: water; ocean; vessel for melting snow for water (when used in dual); area of open water in pack ice; polynya
column4: meghqun ‘down to the ocean’; meghmi ‘in the water, in the ocean’; meghek (dual) ‘large vessel for melting snow for water or for storing water in the house; polynya; open area of water in pack ice’; Tawaten malleglutek mengunani kiyaghtuq. ‘It (the ice) would come in [to shore] and it would stay that way without there being any [open] water.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 2:154); see megh<e>- ‘to drink’, the verbal counterpart of the noun base

column3: hide that has been processed, usually be aging, to remove hair or fur
column4: meqaq akmagtangllaghnaken ‘make a bag out of the proccesed hide’; amiirameng meqameng nateghqaghqiisiin ‘do you have any proccessed hide for boot soles?
mequq ‘it (area of skin)  shed’; meqaa ‘it (animal) shed’ /meqetaa ‘he removed the hair from it’

column3: projection of land into lagoon from barrier isthmus toward east end of Koozata Lagoon on St. Lawrence Is.
one that is or has become furless or hairless; bald person (slang)
column4: meqenghaq yuuk tamaa kaasimaaq ‘a bald headed man has arrived’; amiiraq meqenghaq egsimaat ‘they threw away the furless sealskin’

column3: to cause a skin to shed its hair by allowing it to age
to put one's lips together; to close one's mouth tightly
column4: Pugimaghnaqngama meqellunga meghmun qetgeghtunga. ‘When I was ready to swim, I put my lips together and jumped into the water.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 87); meqenneqesgsaghtuq ‘he kept his lips tightly shut’; meqetngwaaghtuq ‘he closed his mough tightly’

column3: to lack something; to be poor; to be short of something; to be in need of something

column3: to lack (it); be in need of (it)
column4: tamaana meqleqluku ayuqaat ‘they were in need of those things’

column3: to be partially furless; to have bald spots
column4: amiiraq una meqralqaghtupigta ‘this seal skin has a lot of bald spots’; meqralqiisaqumi piniimayaghta ‘if it didn’t have bald spots it would’ve been good’
meqralqaa ilaaghluku enan pinaken ‘just patch the bald spots (of the skin)’
meqsaghtughtuq ‘he went for water to drink’
meghek uqlightekagka saallgaak meraaghinaatalghiik ‘the place where I was hunting had nothing but water, but ice formed on it’; meraaghinaghmi aghvengut ‘they caught a whale in open water’

column3: Maruwtu Point site on St. Lawrence Is.

snow bunting (Plectrophenax nivalis); white wagtail (Motacilla alba)
column4: more generally, any small bird or chick; Kingugmeng qerngughtiikut mesaqaaghaghnun neghesaghqameng. ‘We gathered worms for feeding to the little birds.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 100)

to make a smacking sound with the feet in mud

column4: mesiightuq ‘he dipped food into oil (and ate it)’; mesiighaa ‘he dipped it into oil (and ate it)’ /
mesiighaa ‘he removed the liquid from it’ /

column3: to oil; to get oily; to get or put oil on
column4: mesiighquq ‘he got oily, or put oil on himself’; mesiighqaa ‘he put oil on it, oiled it’ /

vessel for holding or storing oil; gas can; oil can

column4: kakiiquq mesiinekun ‘she is sewing with a sewing machine’
mesiighrugnilnguq ‘greasy food’; mesiingllaghtuq he's making oil from solid fat’

column3: something with a high liquid content
to ooze or run (of a sore or cut)

liquid; juice; water in marshland; wetness on clothing
column4: mesughtuuq ‘it is juicy, wet through and through’; Nunivak paga mesughllaguuq eslallugem kingunganeng. ‘The tundra up there is full of water after the rain.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 98)
also used in the plural, mesuunat, for one comb

column3: to comb the hair; to brush the hair (by extension)
column4: mesuunaaq ‘he combed his (own) hair’; mesuunaa ‘he combed his (another's) hair’ / Fast-eneghpeni aghmigaqillu mesuunaaqillu, ilagpenun nallukesqelluku fast-ellghen. ‘When you fast, wash your face and comb your hair and don’t let your fellows know that you are fasting.’ (Matthew 6.17-18)
used in the plural, mesuunavaget, for one pick

Meteghllugllagnguq taana estaaghaamalghii. ‘That big raven was out sliding on the snow.’ (KALLAG. 17);  Ungipaghaninguq imani meteghlluget, anipat qateperewaaghuyalghiit.  Anipankuk meteghllugenkuk piniqutepigsalghiik, quunpeng qerngaghmetaqelghiik. ‘In the story it is said that back then ravens and owls were white in color. The owl and the raven were friends, always staying with each other.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 3:222)cf. metghaq

column3: eyebrow; eyebrow hair; partition on a seal-oil lamp
to suddenly fly up; to suddenly ascend
column4: anipam qawaak naluguma akuqaghluku metengaghaghtuq ‘the owl  grabbed a landed bird and suddenly flew upward’; tengegkayuk nalugnaqsaghluni metenguq quulmun ‘the airplane was going to land, but it suddenly ascended’

column3: to be too big to fit (garment); to not fit (garment) because it is too small; to outgrow (garment)
column4: mekelghiighem atkuni metengqaa ‘the boy outgrew his parka’; aatkani metengqelluki lliighii angliyalghiimi ‘he can’t fit his clothes anymore because he has grown’

common eider (Somateria mollissima) ; parka made of eider skin with feathers

column4: metngaamsiigtuq ‘he or it is hopping around’ / cf. metngegh-
metngeghtuq ‘he stole away’ / metngeghtestaa ‘he caused her to leave without telling anyone’; metngeqaghvikaa ‘he stole a quick visit to her’

column3: to leap; to jump; spring up
to kidnap; to run off or steal away taking (him/it)
column4: metngeghutaa ‘he stole away with it; kidnapped him’ / Tannget metngeghutkaat, igleghtengngiinaamaluku qenwat upenghaamalghii. ‘The nomads stole him away, kidnapped him, and they were still traveling in springtime.’ (AKIINGQWAGH. 77)
Quyillegni qepghaghluni, qepghaghluni aghyuqsami metngeqaqruguftuq. ‘He worked for the Chukchi, and as he worked when he became homesick, he made his escape.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 2:124)

column3: to speak loudly and/or unintelligibly due to anger; to speak angrily with a raised voice
column4: sameng taana mevliighqaqa? ‘what is he speaking angrily about?’; tazingkuk esgha sameng mevliighqullghiik ‘those two over there are speaking loudly at each other’

mighukaa ‘he finds it unappetizing’; mighuyugtuq ‘he finds something unappetizing’; mighunaghtuq ‘it is unappetizing’; mighuyuglunga neghenghitunga ‘I didn’t eat because I found the food unappetizing’ ; qawaagmeng aghipaan neghelghiit mighuyugtaatnga ‘watching them eating eat raw bird “grossed me out”’
mighyaghtuq ‘he vomited’; mighyaghaa ‘he vomited it out, or vomited on it’ / mighyaghnaghtuq ‘it makes one vomit or want to vomit’; mighyaghyugtuq ‘he feels nauseated’

column3: young female tusked walrus with calf
to melt snow or ice for water
column4: miightuq ‘he melted snow or ice’; miighaa ‘he melted it’ / cf. meq

column3: to make pounding, booming, knocking or thudding noise
column4: Aqlaghaghhneghaniqun mangteghat saaqelghiit miigtaghaqelghiit wetngaaqwaaqelghiit aqlaghami. ‘Whenever it got cold the houses would make a thudding noise and creak in the cold.’  (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 2:260)

column3: to hold a drumming, singing and dance session in a newly completed house
column4: taakunnguq miignaqut ‘they say those people are going to hold a drumming singing and dance session in their new house’

column3: to bang; to tap; to pound (not with hand)
column4: Iiwen unugaqaa qakma miiguutuq. Kii, ilutmun aneghsalghiimi, uka qagit iteghtut taghyut. Qagighllagaat, nenglu eslemkaghaghtaat, …. ‘Just when night came there was pounding out there. Gee, when he tried to breathe, the sea waves came in. Big waves came into it and filled the house, ….’ (AYUM. UNGIP. I:16)

Nunivagem tungangani nenglumi miinglutanga qelpeghsimakanga. Awergha nusugraamakanga. ‘Then she uncovered the wall on the side of the semi-subterranean house facing the tundra. She pulled out furs.’ (AYUM. UNGIP. 1:26)
miisightuq ‘he soaked something’; miisighaa ‘he soaked it’ /
used in the dual, miisiisik, for one such vessel

column3: this time act differently; for a change
to follow one’s husband around as he engages in a certain ritual after catching a whale

column4: Aliighwaaghaa miiwen tengegkayuget tagillequt. ‘The weather is very clear so maybe the airplane will come.’ (Akiingqwagh. 114); Aghtughluku tuqlughaghaataneghmeng miiwen sivumeggni atghaamanayukan aghnaghaat mengteghamun atghaamalghiit. ‘When they had no success in calling her, they thought she might have gone ahead of them, so the girls went toward home.’ (UNGIPAGHAH. 150) "

column3: to be made sad; to make sad; to sadden

Ellngannguq uyvalalukek tuququmaftaak angayuqakek. ‘The old man made the children sad. He said that he’d killed their parents with sorcery.’ (UNGIPAGHAGH. 37)

column3: to feel sad; to be downhearted; to be depressed

column3: edible sea creature with tough skin and dark orange insides
column4: said to be so called because it is thrown to the ground in order to kill it; exact identification undetermined; Miluqutat miluqutaqelghiini uniiqayuget. ‘This kind of sea creature when thrown down repeatedly becomes soft [dies and is edible].’ (SLI JR. DICT. 101)
Chukotkan (R); used in the dual, milutek
miluutaa ‘he threw it’ / miluutaa uyghak qikmimun ‘he threw the rock at a dog’

column3: to bring food over to people in a different place

column4: mingilatut ‘they are scattered’; mingilatii ‘he scattered them’ / mingilatiiq ‘he scattered things’; cf. minglae

column3: young female tusked walrus with calf

column4: mingllegtuq ‘he tidied up’; mingllegtaa ‘he tidied it up’ / cf. mingla

mingugtuq ‘he rubbed himself (e.g. his eyes)’; mingugaa ‘he rubbed it’ / mingugutuq ‘he rubbed or brushed himself against something’; mingugiiq ‘he rubbed something’

high sealskin boot with hair side in, used in summer

column3: to take (it) away (as under the ice (of the water current))
column4: unangkani mughugsimanii peskuwaghulluni ‘he said that the current took his catch away under the ice’; kanaghluninguq mughugtevziimakanga ‘he stepped on slush ice and he almost got sucked under the ice by the current’; Kitum gguutnga mughugaghtekuvgu elpeklu gguten mughugaghsaghqaaguq. ‘If you take away someone’s tooth, your tooth too will be taken away. (“a tooth for a tooth”)’ (Matthew 5:38)

to howl (of dogs, wolves, etc.); to roar

Mulunghituq Taykegergen esnameng taglaamalghii mengteghaminun. ‘Before long Taykegergen came up from the shore to his house.’ (UNGIPAGHAGH. 20); Piniightaa mulunghituq, maaveklu tagiiqluni. ‘He recovered completely before long, and he would come here.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 3:46)"
mumigtuq ‘he turned over’; mumigtaa ‘he turned it over, translated it’; mumigngaaq ‘it is turned over’"

column4: Muugameng neghlunga gguusiqunga. ‘I ate some sweets and had a toothache.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 53)

material that someone has asked to have work done on
to ask someone to do something about (it)
column4: muutaa ‘he asked someone to do something about it’ / yugem atkuk muutaa kakisqelluku aghnamun ‘the man asked the woman to sew up the parka’
muutighvikaa ‘he asked her to do something’; = muutighvike-
muutivikaa ‘he asked her to do something’ / yugem aghnaq muutivikaa ayapghaatanglliisqelluni ‘the man asked the woman to make him mittens’; = muutighvike-
used only with transitive (impersonal subject) interrogative endings: naagu? ‘where is it?, where is he?’; naaki? ‘where are they?’; naakek? ‘where are they2?’; cf. nani, naten

naaka ‘my mother’; naanga ‘his mother’; Maaten ilangani aghnaghaam naani pimakanga, "Ataka, iiwen anengaanka ivaghyaghtughnayaqenka." Naangan pimakanga, "Iwerngaqun iflallequten." ‘One time the girl said to her mother, “I’ll go search for my father and my brothers.” Her mother said to her, “But you’ll get lost.” (UNGAZ. UNGIP. 13); cf. anaana, enaangaay

column3: to break; to cause to break; to run make a break for it; for weather to become bad
column4: naafquq ‘he made a break for it’ or ‘it (the weather) got bad’; naafqaa ‘he broke it’ / naafqiiq ‘he broke something’; tangyeghmigegka ifkaghlukek naafqagka ‘dropping my wristwatch I broke it’

column3: at the time of bad weather
to get stormy; for a blizzard to arise
column4: naaftuq or naaftaa ‘it is getting stormy’

column3: to smell; to sniff; to kiss
column4: naaghtuq (or naaghutuq) ‘he smelled something’; naaghaa ‘he smelled it, kissed her’ / naaghutuk ‘they2 kissed’

column3: to anesthetize with ether or the like
to sniff; to smell an odor for a while
column4: naaghwaaghtuq ‘he sniffed’; naaghwaaghaa ‘he sniffed it’ / Mesiighpagni meghnuutaqa naaghwaaneghmeng. ‘I am tired of smelling the odor of oil.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 109)
naagsaghtuq ‘he is target shooting’; naagsaghaa ‘he's target shooting with it (the gun)’ / naagsaghvikaa ‘he's target shooting at it’; cf. nakegh-
naagtuq ‘he tripped’ / uyghagkun naagtuq ‘he tripped on a rock’; = aagte2-; cf. nakligh-

column3: where is it?; where is he/she?; somewhere
column4: naagu suflugaqa? ‘where is my gun?’; Kayngeghllagem pimakanga, "Quyngiq qerngughsaghtughnaqaqa." Taagken aviilluni, aviiteghllagluni iitghumalghii. Aapsimakanga nanevgam, "Qayugham naagu?" ‘The bear said to him, "I am about to go gather the reindeer." After being away for a long time, he came back inside. The old man asked him, "So then, where is it (are they)?"’ (AYUM. UNGIP. III:15); Egllullgaaftuqlu taawa naagu suflugmeng ivaghnaghhaq. Tamaa copper-et, legan taakwavek suqlughlluki, wayameng sameng, wayaghtuftuqlu copper-meng tamaa. Sufluget taaqiit. ‘Evidentally it had a stove, and somewhere a stovepipe was to be sought. They bent copper (sheets) and wired (that is, wrapped) it with copper wire. They finished the stovepipe.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 2:166)

column3: aunt, in the sense of one's uncle's wife; bad mother; stepmother through father's remarriage

column4: used in the dual, naalkak, for the seat of one pair of pants

naalkaa ‘he found it’ / naalkutuq ‘he found something’; naalkefikaa ‘he found something of his on her (she had stolen it)’; Iyegaategka iflakagka estugaghmeng naalkagka. ‘I found my eyeglasses that I’d lost at the store.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 104)

column3: to fix or get fixed; to repair; to correct; to align or adjust
column4: naallghutuq ‘it’s gotten fixed’; naallghutaa ‘he fixed it, adjusted it’ /

column3: to be sufficient; to be enough
column4: naamaaq ‘it is sufficient’ / qiipaghaghqaq naamaaq ‘there is enough parka material’
Naamakaghtaqa kaviiq angyangnatkaghqastun. ‘I got enough fox (pelts) to buy a boat.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 104)
naamakaa ‘he fits into it’/ atkuka naamakaqa ‘my parka fits me’ (literally: ‘I fit into my parka’)

column3: to go as far as; to complete
column4: naamigtaa ‘he completed it’ or ‘he went as far as it’ /… piyaaluteng tuvaq naamiglluku, uteghmun qiivyalghiimeng, uyughaat aviituq. ‘… walking along they got to the shorefast ice, and when they went back home their brother was gone.’ (AYUM. UNGIP. I:12)

column3: to come to an end; to be all gone; to be consumed; to be finished; be used up
column4: naanguq ‘it is all gone’ or ‘(it is) the end’ / naangtaa ‘he used it up’; naangutuq kufimeng ‘he is out of coffee’; naangyaghaq ‘the ending’; cf. naangquq

column3: fat (especially cow walrus); cow walrus blubber

column4: used in the dual, naangngwaaghhaatek, for one swing
naangngwaaghaghtuq ‘he was swinging’; naangngwaaghaghtaa ‘he is swinging it’

column3: ivory piece on keel of boat
piece of ivory (hard part); tusk (hard part)
column4: cf. naange-; Uunghat neghighluku naangqumeng tuugqelghiit. ‘Harpoons of times past had ivory points.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 105)

column3: to be nowhere else, but ... (in a certain place)

column3: to catch with trap or net
column4: naaptuq ‘he caught something; naaptaa he caught it’ / Negaghpagput akimigaq naapsimalghii amaghtumeng. ‘Our net caught fifteen humpback salmon.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 105); Naapta kaviiq esghaghaqa taawa unkusegpegun. ‘I saw a fox getting caught there in your trap.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 105)

column3: to smell (have a smell); emit an aroma
column4: Amik qelpeghngamaluku imaninguq sangwaa naaqaaluni neqniipiglleghhii aana. ‘The door being  open something there coming out, very delicous, had an aroma .’ (IGHSANI. AFSENG. 2)

column3: scalp of animal including skin from face
to estimate; to predict; to measure

column4: siqineq naasaghaakun piituq ‘the sun rose in the direction indicated by his marker’; angyat naayghaq naasaghaqluku taglaghtut ‘the boat went home using the mountain as a marker’

naasiightuq ‘he tasted something’; naasiighaa ‘he tasted it’ / naasiiqaghhu taana ugkem qayaa ‘taste that meat broth please’; naasiighutuq ‘he tasted or experienced it’; naasiighutuq kayum qayaaneng eslami gaaqameng ‘he tasted some broth from sculpin that had been boiled outdoors’; naasiighutuq tawatelngughmeng teghigniqelleghmeng alikegpenakek angayuqagni talwa ‘he  experienced that kind of enjoyment without fearing his parents' reaction’
naasqiquq ‘he had or has a headache’ / naasqiqsagutuq ‘he started having a headache’; naasqiqnaghtuq ‘it causes headaches’
naasqwa ‘his head’; Aawyaghllak, naasqughllaga uuknaghllaga kiiluugteghllakaq. ‘He had a blood clot; this side of his entire head was all covered with cuts.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 3:40)
Naasquvrak mesiighmeng imighaqa. ‘I filled the bowl with seal oil.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 106)

column4: used in the plural, naavellghet, used for one ruin

Enkaangam qamumun iknaqut naavyighyaghqaanghisimaghmeng ayuqut. ‘And so they were strong for hauling and they would not become tired out.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 2:78)

Nayvak Lake just west of Old Chaplino (Ungaziq) in Chukotka

NANGAGH. 2:248)
nafuqaa ‘he feels broken-hearted over him, or it’ /

naghullegtuq ‘he harpooned something’; naghullgaa ‘he harpooned it’ /

ukaaghita naguqutanga mekelghiiq pivakepigtaat ‘they really adore and care for their daughter-in-law’s first child’; cf. naguqaq

column4: = na; Nakaa, imatuq pilleqsinga, qepghaqaghllaguunga. ‘No, I don’t think I’ll go, I have lots of work to do.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 109)"

column4: see item 99 on lst in Oozeva et al. 2004
nakaghtaghlluggaghmeng qiipaghiighaanga ‘she made a snowshirt for me out of a prized piece of imported material’

naken pizin? ‘where did you come from?’; look under nani

column3: to hook as with a gaff

Ilangani tamaakut piyaat yuget, tevrat, uqlighhutaqelghiit meghhaghni nalighmeng iighwilnguum kangitegkeni. ‘Some of the men are hunting by walking on the ice, looking out for seals, in the open water or on a cove of a large cake of ice.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 1:130); Maalghuguuk, nalighmeng pingayut allakullghiit sivunelget maani Sivuqami ramket. ‘Two or three clans here in St. Lawrence Is. have different backgrounds.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 1:204)"

can be used either as an appositive or as a selectional base: naliq qikmin qilugta? or naliit qikmivek qilugta? ‘which of your dogs barked?’; nalim qikmima qilugtaten? or naliita qikmima qilugtaten? ‘which of my dogs barked at you?’; cf. natu

column3: to be undecided on which to take; to have a difficult time choosing
column4: nunavaget ima ateghaatut guutestengngunateng naliqegtim ‘the herd of walrus dived into the water from ice before we had a chance to shoot on account of (us) being unsure which to shoot’; natmun pilleghqameng naliqegtilunga upuupeng pinghitunga ‘I wasn’t sure where to go, and so I didn’t go’

column3: that which corresponds in time or space
column4: nallangakun ‘through the time or space which corresponds to it’; nallangighaa ‘it is in line with it’
Naalkun pama angyaput tamlagtut ‘our boat landed at North Beach’

column3: to run into; to meet; to encounter
column4: nallaghaa ‘he ran into him’ / Ungazighmiit angyiit nallaghaput taan’gani. ‘We ran into the boats from Chaplino out there.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 110)

column3: to pay off bills; to direct something (e.g. gun) at something or someone; to move facing (against) something; to pay back
column4: nallangighaa ‘he paid it/him off, or back’Angyaghhaat nallangiitut esneghagnun. ‘The little boat is in line with the lagoon.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 110)

column3: to lose something; to forget where things are
column4: unangyaghluni nallavraghaa, qayughllagnguq nallunapigtuq ‘he caught a seal but he lost it, because it was difficult to see’; tumet naantulangi nallavraghluki iflangwaaghamalghii ‘he lost track of where the trail was and so he was lost’

Naangan qamaken pimakanga, “Sangwaa qakemna miigtaghta nalleq, kangsughsiin?” ‘He mother from in there said to him, “What is that making knocking noises too much out there, are you too big to fit in?” (IGHSANI. AFSENG. 14); Nallegha tawatenngam, qaa, qayumeng. ‘That’s too much, please, no mroe tea.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 110); Ilughaqa nalleghaghhaghmeng anglimaa! ‘My cousin has grown so tall!’ (SLI JR. DICT. 110)"

column3: how big!; what a long time!

column4: nalleghiituq ‘it has taken a long time, it is very big’ /
nallekevyeghaghtuq ‘he acted crazy’ / nallekevyeghaataa ‘he acted crazy over it’
nalleqiiyaghutuq ‘he made something equal’; nalleqiiyaghutaa ‘he made it even’ /

column3: to fix; to correct; to set straight
column4: Enkaangam tawani mitiingemi nallghusaghaqa Sivuqaq unguvaviga qutem yugan. ‘And so there at the meeting I sought to clarify that St. Lawrence Is. was a land where people could live (well).’ (PANGEGH. 52)

sivuyagtem samanlluku aghveq nallimsaghluku aghveqaa ‘the striker guessed where the whale was underwater, and struck it’; Aqeftapagmeng nallimsaghluku Uuyneq tevyalghiinga akivaghquutkaniimalghiinga ‘I went from Aqeftapak hoping to get to Uuyneq, but I was little off to the south’

column4: nalluuq ‘he is ignorant’ / Ilangi yugem nallupigtaqelghiit. ‘Some people are so stupid.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 111)

column4: nallunaghtuq ‘it is hard to understand’ / naayghat nullunaghtut umegneghmi ‘the mountains are hard to find in a blizzard’

to mark so as to make easier to locate
column4: nalluniighaa ‘he marked it’ / Sazinga? Tagneghtestaghpenga; uyavaneng esghaghaqnaghaatnga ukazit, afsengaat. Natenngam ivaghiniighnaqsinga? Nalluniighutestaghpenga! ‘What did you do to me? You made me black; form afar hares and mice can see me. How am I going to hunt game? You have caused me to be marked such that I can be easily spotted.’ (AANGHHAQ 28)

column3: to be easy to know or perceive; to be readily visible
column4: naayghat aliineghmi ‘the mountains are easy to see on a clear day’

column4: nalpaghtuq ‘he's very excited’ / angyalek nalpaghtuq aghvengluni ‘the boat captain is elated over catching a whale’

column3: to be careless; to be untidy (especially in housekeeping)
column4: nalqigangituq ‘he is careless, untidy’ / cf. nanqigte-

elpesineng nalqik angyangnaqitek ‘try to get a boat of your own’; nalqik allgeghuteqaghlleghhiini pinightuq ‘to get something for one’s own use is good’

column3: relative (kin); fellow clan member; family member; community member

column3: to jump up and down; jump or hop around
column4: qikmiq petugtaaq nalughqutaghluni qenwat iikutuq ‘the dog jumped up and down so much that it broke out of it’s leash’; ukazit nalughqutameng igleghnequt ‘rabbits get around pretty well by hopping’

column3: decoy duck; duck used as decoy
dead bird used as a decoy
to jump across; to land with
column4: nalugutuq ‘he jumped across something’; nalugutaa ‘he jumped across it, landed carrying it’ / nalugutfikaa ‘he jumped across to it’

column3: airfield or airport; landing strip; place where birds, planes, etc., land
column4: nalugvikaa ‘it landed on it’; Sighinek wata angliiquq, nekeftaqiit  nutaghat aangelghiit guygut, aanguq igaghviga, aghalighviga, nalugvilguuq vær’tolyot-mun. ‘(The town of) Sireniki grows more and more; they erect large new buildings; its school is large and also its clinic; it has a landing place for helicopters (vær’tolyot).’ (AANGHHAQ 153)

nanaaghmeng kamiighnaqniiquq nuliighminun ‘he says that his wife will make him boots out of polar bear skin’; qimugsiqayuget neghighluku nanaaghmeng aqupiitiqayuget ‘long ago those who went by dog sled used polar bear skin as a mat’
nanevgaghtuq or nanevgaghaa ‘he has grown or is growing old’ /

Nanevgaaghtukung piniyugtegpenaamta. Ilangi qawaaget anglaminat, whangkutung aliitaqukung kiiginaghmi. ‘We2 are becoming old men without having any joy in life. Other birds are a delight to behold, but we can be seen readily only in summer.’ (AANGHHAQ 28)

column3: way of life; culture; personality; behavior; form; lore
column4: nangaghallghat Quutmiit whangkunneng allangughtaa whani kiyaghtaallemnni, taawa ‘the way of life of the Siberians (Chukotkan Yupik people) at this time is different from ours for certain’; aghnaghaam taam nangaghalleghqek atami nangaghallghegketun ayuquk elngaatall ‘that girl's personality certainly resembles her father's’; angyam taam nangaghallgha ulimanaken whanga ulimaamtun uutun ayuqekanighluku ‘make that boat's form similar to the one I made’; lion-em nangaghallghi kitim nangaghallghistun ayuqelghiit ‘a lion's behavior is similar to that of a domestic cat’

column3: way of life; culture; personality; behavior; form; lore
column4: Sivuqam Nangaghnegha ‘the Lore of St. Lawrence Island’ (book series title)

column3: to form a big snow-drift; to cover with snow
to take an unplanned side-trip or extension of a trip
column4: Angyaneng uteghninghilkumta nangenqaamaninakefsikut Ungazimun. ‘If we don’t return from the boat hunting trip you should know that we have gone on to Chaplino (or to Chukotka in general).’ (SLI JR. DICT. 112)

column3: to give up hope; to go to a place and continue on; to stay too long
column4: nangeteghughtuq ‘he gave up hope’ / nangeteghuutaa ‘he gave up hope for him or it’; telaanangalghiit kelutmun qiivluteng taaga nangeteghughtut ‘the sailboat turned toward land, and then continued sailing toward it’

nangghayugtuq ‘he is interesting in something, excited by something’; nangghanaghtuq ‘it is interesting’; nanghghanaq ‘interesting thing’; iviighennguq esgha nangghanalghiit ayumiq sama esnami uglaghluteng iglakgalegnguq ‘they say that whaling ceremonies with singing were very interesting long ago down at the beach’"

column3: to feel excited; to be interested
to be uninteresting; to be boring
to be right; to be correct
to disapprove of someone or something; to criticize someone or something; to denigrate someone through comparison with another
column4: nangghuuq or nangghughiiq ‘he is criticizing someone or something’ /

column3: to criticize; to denigrate (him) through comparison; to disapprove of (him)
column4: nangghukaa ‘he criticized it’/ yugem nangghukumakanga panigmi aghneghsaghtulleghqaa saaqwlimeggnun ‘the man disapproved of his daughter's decision to spend the day with their next door neighbor’

column3: to try; to test; to experience; to challenge
column4: nanghiightuq ‘he tried something’; nanghiighaa ‘he tried it’ / Ataasimeng aghneghmi naani qavaaluku nanghiighnaluni pugimameng pimalghii. ‘One day while his mother was sleeping he decide to try swimming.’ (QUNGLUK 17); Neghighluku nanghiighutaqelghiit kilgaani esghaatuuneghmeggni, allakutunneghmeggnillu. ‘Long ago men would challenge each other when they met in the wilderness especially if they were from different places.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 111); Wiin sivukluteng pikusinun maligsaaghulluteng unangniighmun piinliqayuget liitkayuget tawaten nanghiighluku mughunniiq. ‘In order to learn they would go out with those experienced in hunting on the ice and learn from them and thus they learned to hunt game by actually experiencing it.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 1:130); Sivuqam igleghneghani tamaakut aqelqat kaanneghata nanghiighyaghqaawaqelghiit, iknaqetulngi, sukatulngi. ‘According to the custom of Gambell whenever those visitors would arrive they would have trials concerning strength and speed.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 1:48)
nanghiiquuq ‘he tried to do something’; nanghiiqwaa ‘he tried to do something to it ‘/

column3: to start going or coming over to someone’s place much more often
column4: sangami taana nangigalighllaguuq whangkunnun ‘I wonder why he is coming to our place more often now’

column3: to gaze (into the distance); to stare
column4: nangliiguq ‘he gazed (into the distance)’/ nangliitkaa ‘he gazed at it’; cf. nunii-
nangllaghtuq or nangllaghaa ‘he cooled off’ / cf. nenglek

column3: to get a chill (of a person)
column4: nangllaghaghsaqunang aanegkuvek ‘don't get a chill when you go out’

column3: edge of a harpoon’s tip;  blade cover
to open one's eyes very wide

column4: nangllegyugtuq ‘he feels pity or compassion’; nangllekaa or nangllegyukaa ‘he pities her, feels compassion toward her’; nangllegnaghtuq ‘he is pitiful’; nangllegtaghtuq ‘he is a compassionate person’"
Aghveghmun tawavek nangllegsiisiq. ‘(It (the ceremony) was) a supplication in regard to (catching) whale.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 1:222)

column3: to be alerted suddenly while doing something
column4: kelengayugem saam elpegyugem, qimugsighhaq igleghtekestaghngaaghmi qikmii nangqalugpagtaalluteng aygumun  qiifqaghulluku teghiighusimakangat ‘while the man was dog sledding something alerted his dogs and they ran towards the north’; unugmi taghnughhaat ilungani naghaalghiit tenglugtughluki nangqalugpagtaasimalghiit ‘while the children were playing at night, someone’s knocking alerted them’
cf. naangquq; Nangqwalget nunivagmi naayvaan esnengakun ighnikayuget. ‘Yellow-billed loons lay eggs in the tundra on the shore of the its lake.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 112)

column3: to get rubbed, chafed or blistered; to long for someone; to get worn out

column4: nangrughquq ‘it blistered’; nangrughqaa ‘it made it blister’ /

column3: male partner of male, from another clan, with whom one would cooperate and exchange wives

column4: Kingungitneng avaqutama nangughyugumaanga elngaatall. ‘After my children [left] I got very lonely.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 113)

column3: site on the coast east of Gambell
to wince; to hesitate; to fear
column4: nangyaghtuq ‘he winced’ / nangyaghnaghtuq ‘it is dangerous’; nangyaghyugtuq ‘he is fearful’; nangyaghtaghtuq ‘he is always fearful’; nangyaqluku qaprak siku ateghvikengita ‘he felt that it was too risky to go on the moving ice so he didn't go on it’; nangyaamakanga ungipaanneghmeng nanevgaq qinuumsi yugneng meghmi pelighqelghiineng ‘he fears telling the sickly old man about the men who perished in the sea’
Nangzeghaat neqesghaaluteng piniraaghinaat. ‘The hard seal blubber is good for [fox] bait.’ (SLI JR. DICT. 113)
interrogative demonstrative adverb; navek ‘to where?’; natmun ‘toward where?’; naken ‘from where?’; nagun? ‘which way, through where?’; naanta? ‘where is it?’; cf. na-, naten

column3: covered part of stern of boat
column4: Chukotkan (R); cf. naniq1 and the possibility that an oil lamp was kept in this protected area of the boat

column3: to feel like one is getting to one’s destination fast
column4: ullghitagnekun igleghsuwhaaghaqngami nanivegyugluni repall gginani saapegkaa ‘when he was first travelling on a snowmachine, he felt he was getting to where he has going so fast that he covered his face (in fear)’
cf. nalqiganite-; Nanqigtigpenasi ilagpesineng enkaam Kiyaghneghem nanqiggneghillisi, …. ‘Do not judge your fellows and God will not judge you, ….’ (Matthew 7.1)
… luuraq avutkistegpek tuunayukangaten nanqigtistemun. ‘… it may happen then that your accuser will turn you over to the judge.’ (Matthew 5.25)

Kitum avutkumakangaten seghletun pimaniluni, ilaliighaghhnaken aglaasimaluten nanqigtivigmun, …. ‘If someone accuses you of wrongdoing you should come to terms with him as you are going to court, ….’ (Matthew 5.25)

nanughtuq ‘it is hanging lengthwise’; nunughtaa ‘he hung it lengthwise’; nanughngaaq ‘it is hung lengthwise’; atkuni qelghusimaa nanughtaghtesqelluku ‘he had his parka be hung lengthwise’; nanughngaan pinaken ‘hang it up lengthwise’

column3: skin pants with special design on back worn only by strongest men

column4: Nanuq igleghtaquq nunmaakw, sikut pakigaqluki, naaghwaaghumaghmi. ‘The polar bear moves slowly, pulling itself across the ice, sniffing as it goes.’ (AANGHHAQ 74)

but instead; such being the case; consequent to the fact that; in as much as

Sameng naqam seghleliighmeng avangituq. ‘Whichever one that will be stronger, the other one will fear him. He will start obeying him. It is that way. Such being the case, there wasn’t any trouble.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 1:16); Elngaatall taakut piniqegkangat. Naqam avaqutiilnguk. Taawanginaq nulighqutiinalghiik. ‘They liked him very much. That being in as much as they had no children. They were just a man and wife.’ (UNGAZ. UNGIP. 44)"
ilangit naqamalla ayveghaasimaat ‘the others are lucky they got walruses’

Esghaghyaqufsiki Ungazighmiit aatkiit nuqutupaaghrugllaaguut, nasiilnguut nasaperameng nasaqelghiit. ‘You should have seen the Chaplinio people with their parkas without hoods open at the neck, haaving hats instead of hoods.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 2:198)
Taagken Ukaamangatem nasani mataghsimakanga. Mataghsaqminigu gginaa yugem esghaamakanga. ‘Then Ukaamangan pulled back her parka hood. When she took it off the man saw her face.’ (UNGAZ. UNGIP. 37)

DICT. 106)

used mainly with transitive subordinative endings; neghighluku piiqsalghiikut ‘a long time ago we used to do this’; Iteghyaghaam  Anagutaghmun  neghighluku  apellgha ‘told long ago by Iteghyaghaq to Anagutaq’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 3:222); Neghighluku sangwaat yuget naken kaaanneghata maakumiingungilnguut aqelqat. Sivuqam igleghneghani tamaakut aqelqat kaanneghata nangiighyaghqaawaqelghiit, iknaqetulngi, sukatulngi. ‘Long ago whenever some people from anywhere, not local people, they were visitors. In accordance with the custom of Gambell when they arrived there would be competions concerning strength and speed.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 1:48)

exact identification of kelp undetermined; the snake is known through the Bible and from contact with outsiders; Kayagtekumsi penniighestun qungangitnilngughestun amaat lliighlequsi enkaam kelengalusi nemeghyastun, … ‘I am sending you out like sheep into the midst of wolves; so be as wise as serpents ….’ (Matthew 10.16)

column4: used in the ablative-modalis as the indefinite object of the verb taaqe- ‘to finish’: neneghmeng taaqluni ‘after he finished eating’; North Star usiista tagiiquq. Aghnequn neneghmeng taaqegkufsi igaghnaanghitusinguq. ‘The North Star freighter is coming. This afternoon when you’re done eating there will be no more school.’ (SULUWET 3); Neneghmeng taaqsameng, tawatengwaaq tuguluku qayuusiq wine-eghraghameng imalek, …. ‘When they finished eating, He lifted that cup full of wine, ….’ (1 Corinthins 11.25)

also nengllugta; nengllugutet ‘a family’; Paapgaq iteghluni qukiitgun nengllugutmi aghuliighumalghii. ‘After coming in Paapgaq stopped in the midst of his family members.’ (IGHSANI. AFSENG.16)

this is the Yupik form of the Eskimo word which has entered English as "igloo"; the semi-subterranean house was used by Yupik people on St. Lawrence Is. until replaced by the dome-shaped walrus-hide covered Chukchi-style house, mangteghaq or mengteghaq, (now referred to as mangteghapik or mengteghapik), in the late 1800’s or early 1900’s; Nenglu qafsin'guyaghta uglaghraak qaya paamna nenglulighvigilnguq tangeghtughllak. ‘One can’t say how many semi-subterranean houses there were but it was quite a few, but up there the ground was too hard and there were no semi-subterranean houses.’ (SIVUQ. NANGAGH. 3:18)

column3: site on north shore of Koozata Lagoon
